Pawtec wall charger is a compact 2 port charger with retractable prongs. Due to its nice size it takes up just one slot on a power strip. It is 2"L x 2"W x 1"H and weighs 2.8 oz. The package includes a travel pouch.

I tested Pawtec wall charger with Samsung Nexus phone and iPad Mini tablet.

I run the same set on tests on each battery pack I own, so I can compare them to each other using "apples to apples" comparison. This set of tests allows me to compare different chargers as well as see how performance changes with each upgrade of the operating system. I am including the details of the tests below for those who want to see the nitty gritty.

For those who are interested in the bottom line this battery pack worked consistently with both devices and charged the devices charging them at slightly below average rate.

 To prolong battery life
==================================

Li-ion batteries do not need to be fully charged nor is it desirable to do so. In fact, it is better not to fully charge, because high voltages stresses the battery. Li-ion should never be discharged too low. This is why battery manufacturers typically ship batteries with a 40 percent charge. The low charge state reduces aging-related stress while allowing some self-discharge during storage. If you plan to store the battery without using it apply a partial charge before a long storage period.

 How I tested this wall charger
==================================

I use a USB current monitor and a charging test to test each port. The current monitor shows the voltage and the current flowing between the battery and the device.

I started running these tests when my Android devices had HoneyComb operating system so I was able to observe the improvements in charging with different version of the Android OS. Before 4.21 I could only get fast charging on 1A port, and would get bad performance on 2.1A port on my Android devices. After upgrade to Jelly Bean 4.21 I see the same performance on 2A and 1A ports as it is controlled by the device negotiating the protocol with the charger. Google reverse engineered the Apple protocol and now my Android devices typically charge similar in speed on both ports of a good charger. This is not true for Apple devices. They do better on ports designed for Apple (2.1A ports).

An addition variable for Android devices is whether a data cable or charging cable is used to charge the device. The charging cables short the two data connections together (rendering them useless for data transfer), but this fools devices to see the cable as an AC power connection, and thus accept the higher current of the charging source.

The 10 minutes test consists of charging each mobile device on each port of the battery pack for 10 minutes and measure how much each unit was charge in that 10 minute period. Since the charging speed is non-linear I start charging each device from approximately the same charge level. I use Battery App by Elvison to determine how each device recognized the charging source. 'AC' status means the charging is at full charging rate. 'USB' status indicates charging at a lower charging rate. 'Discharging' status means that the charging rate is below the power that the device is consuming so it slows down the discharge rate but does not re-charge.

 Test Results:
======================

 Samsung Galaxy Nexus Phone
--------------------------
Port 1: AC charging rate ----- 4% change in charge in 10 minutes
Port 1: current monitor: ~~~~~ 0.95A and 5.12V

Port 2: AC charging rate ----- 4% change in charge in 10 minutes
Port 2: current monitor: ~~~~~ 0.96A and 5.12V

 iPad Mini Tablet
--------------------------
Port 1: AC charging rate ----- 1% change in charge in 10 minutes
Port 1: current monitor: ~~~~~ 1.46A and 5.10V

Port 2: AC charging rate ----- 3% change in charge in 10 minutes
Port 2: current monitor: ~~~~~ 1.53A and 5.12V

 Summary
------------------
This is a small 2 port charger. Its charging rate is somewhat below average, but it works well for overnight charging and when compact size matters I like it. It takes up just one slot on the old fashioned power strip, and since I am always running out of space on my power strips this is a big plus for this charger.

This charger is provided by Pawtec.

Ali Julia review
summary: Takes up only one slot on a power strip

Background:
I have purchased a lot of car chargers in the past. One of the biggest issues I had is that after a week or so, the ports would become really loose and your devices would only charge if you got the adapter in the perfect position. Just from opening the package and holding this adapter, I can tell that it is much better quality than ones I have used in the past.

There are a lot of car chargers out there, but what makes this one worth buying?:

Pros:
1) There are 3 USB ports
2) Of the three ports, one is 2.1amps, one is 2.0amps, and the other is 1.0amps. That means you can charge BOTH an iPad/tablet AND a phone at the same time
3) Mat grey finish is applied where cables are unplugged a lot to keep from scratching. (yes this is just a cosmetic feature, but it makes everyone feel better when there electronics don't get scratched!)
4) EXTREMELY SMALL

Cons:
1) No replaceable fuse

This car charger simply does what it states. It will charge any device through USB while your 12V plug on your car is on. It provides users with the ability to use GPS aps in their car without completely draining there battery when they get to their destination

Would you buy it for a friend/recommend it?

The sensors in the headset itself are a huge game changer.  You can play this for hours and not get sick or motion sick.  That faster response time because of the sensors offers that much more immersion.

In the next couple of years when Samsung offers a 4K screen this will be amazing technology.  The only thing holding it back is the screen door effect and sub HD image that you're looking at.  That's the phone's limitation, however, not the headset.

Controls are intuitive.  It's mostly comfortable and doesn't feel heavy on your face.  My only gripe (and I'm surprised someone aftermarket hasn't come up with an answer) is the face pad.  It's thin and now terribly comfortable.  Some light manages to sneak in around my face.  I understand Samsung not being able to put a leatherette padded cover on it but I'd love to see someone aftermarket get on this.  Like the kind of foam material you get on higher quality headphones.  I've bought replacement pads for $3-4.  No reason one can't be made for this headset for $10.  Get on it aftermarket sellers!

Cheap as this is, if I had read the review I'm about to leave I would not have purchased this item. This is a sorry offering from Motorola and their quality appears to be in decline.

My first moto headset (don't remember the number) was cheap but fine. I then decided to upgrade to an H790 which wasn't cheap but not too expensive. It lasted for a few years of light but regular use and finally the speaker gave out. (harsh treble and difficult to understand voices) The microphone and speaker quality were excellent for a long time, and no issues with the battery life even to this day.

Now enter the Motorola HK250. The sound was okay, the microphone mediocre at best, but it was inexpensive. After less than a month of use, it is now a brick. This is unacceptable even at this price point.

It had been left dormant (turned off and battery level "high") for a few days and now does nothing when you turn it on. Putting it on the charger resulted in a rapidly blinking red light, for which there is no definition on their relatively pathetic and useless "light status chart". Motorola has yet to reply as to how you can tell if it's fully charged by the single multi-colored light on the face. I do already know what the rapidly blinking red light and no functionality mean.

Even if I get it replaced on warranty I'd never trust it as a primary device. I might not feel this way had it failed a bit sooner. My guess is either a garbage battery or they skimped on the charge system components.

Update: I found no way to initialize a ticket on Motorola's website without creating an account. I opted to try the phone method, but after waiting with no response for over thirty minutes I ended the call.
Apple iPhone 4 doesn't recognize it.

I purchased this adapter to install an aftermarket radio into my 2004 GMC Envoy.  It was very easy to install and works as described.  The "chime" that it replaces the factory chime with is a bit awkward sounding at first, but it isn't all that bad.

Just incase you're not entirely sure what this does...  In some vehicles (I'm not sure exactly which ones so you'll have to do your own research), the factory installed radios control various other functions such as the chimes.  In my 2004 Envoy, the radio also stays on after you turn off the truck until you open a door.  This feature and the chimes are lost if you remove the factory radio without using the GMOS-01 adapter.

Just make sure it functions properly BEFORE you button everything up!  I received a faulty unit the first time around and had to wait for a couple of days to get a new one.  If your chimes don't work  (the unit's default volume is loud enough) or if the radio stays on after you open your door, then it's a bad unit.

OH, and don't forget to buy an antenna adapter as well if you're installing into a newer GM!  They use a mini antenna connection that you have to convert into the larger type that aftermarket radios use.  Amazon sells the adapter for about ten bucks or so.

The sample received here for evaluation is the 100% clear version of this case. The clear version differs from some other similar cases sold here at Amazon in that it has a frosted bezel rather than the optically clear bezel some other cases have. In addition, the protection this case sports has a bit more cushion than cases which superficially seem identical or at least similar.

Clear cases have advantages over opaque, colored cases. The obvious one is that they preserve the color scheme of your iPhone. Why ask for a silver cased iPhone only to hide it in an orange or green case? Less obvious, using a clear case, you can set your phone to LED flash on alerts (Settings, General, Accessibility, Flash LED on Alerts). In action, the entire bezel of the case flashes when the phone tries to alert you. This is not only decorative, but means you won't miss an alert due to your volume being way down or the phone on mute. Personally, I think it just looks great.

I've inadvertently dropped the iPhone several times onto a wood floor and once onto a concrete driveway while in this case with no damage whatsoever to the phone. Given the light weight and lack of bulk of this case, this demonstrates excellent protection.

Overall, a serviceable well made case which offers both style and function at a reasonable price.
Nice case

I just received my new BlueAnt Z9i in the mail yesterday and couldn't wait to get it open and on my ear!  I love new toys!  Let me give just a little background.

I bought the original Z9 back in March of this year and loved it.  It was my first Bluetooth headset.  I had no problems pairing it with my Motorola Razr.  However, there were some subsequent connection issues, such as taking too long to go from 'idle' to 'standby' and some dropping issues which were probably due to some kind of interference.  I still haven't figured the latter out.

I'm also the proud new owner of an iPhone 3G that I just got three days ago.  So I had a couple of days to try out my Z9 with the new iPhone and see if some of the issues I had with the Razr would still be the same with the iPhone.  I'm glad to say that after just a couple of days using the Z9 with the iPhone, the 'weak signal' notifications I was getting with my Razr are non-existent with the iPhone.

So, now for the Z9i.  In just a day of use, I like some of the new features already.  The first is the change from the old to the new in how to disconnect a call.  On the original Z9, in order ot hang up a call, I had to hold the MFB for three seconds.  On the new Z9i, a single click will do the same.  It also seems to connect faster than the Z9.

One thing I have noticed that I don't like is the intermittent 'empty room echo' sound that I've been hearing on occasion.  It's hard to say if it's the iPhone or the Z9i.  I haven't had that problem with the original Z9 paired with the iPhone in the two days I had them together.  I'll have to do some more testing and investigating.

Having used the original for several months, I was already comfortable with the fit and form and have no complaints with the new one.  I like the fact that BlueAnt ships an additional earpiece.  The original didn't come with an extra.

Overall this is a great sounding earpiece.  It's small and lightweight - the reasons I bought the original.  The noise isolation is great - not really sure why they have 'standard' and 'max' isolation modes, but they both work very well.  The battery life is very good.  Because I use it everyday, I have to charge it often.

One other thing that I forgot to mention was the wind test.  I have yet to test it in windy conditions.  The original Z9 was 'OK' when I was going down the highway at cruising speed with the windows down AND TALKING.  The microphones worked great at isolating my voice and cutting out the background noise.  However, when I stopped talking to listen to the other party, they could hear all of the whooshing from the wind because that's all the Z9 picked up. I love the Nexus 6P, but it does feel fragile to me, and I was very paranoid about breaking it (this is a criticism I have of every metal/glass phone, including the iPhone). This case makes it feel WAY more durable. It is very snug and gives a very re-assuring solid feel to the phone. I am no longer worried about scratching or gouging it, or breaking the back glass when I set it down. I don't know how well it would survive a fall (definitely better than the naked case would), but I don't feel like I have to baby it all the time, which was the one thing I didn't like about the phone.

While I prefer the soft-touch plastic on some of their other products, this plastic/rubber has a very nice grippy feel to it. I'm never worried about the phone slipping out of my hand as I was with the naked case. As another pleasant surprise, it seems to be completely impervious to fingerprints! I mean, I can't even put fingerprints on it deliberately. The Volume/Power buttons are fully enclosed and have solved my previous gripe about the buttons being too sensitive...now they are perfect. Very clicky and responsive, but not so responsive that they activate just by brushing against them like before.

The cut outs are all where they need to be, and some actually enhance the device. The fingerprint reader is actually a lot easier to use for me with the case on. The USB-C port is plenty big enough to accommodate all the cables I use...I don't struggle trying to plug it in. The case is also easy to put on and take off, despite fitting so snuggly.

I do like the styling, but would have preferred more minimalism...The matte plastic finish looks really nice IMO, but I'm not as big a fan of the faux carbon-fiber insert things. I don't hate them, but I'd have preferred something that matches the rest of the case. And like everyone else, I could do without the Spigen logo on the back.

Otterbox used to be my preferred case, but honestly, I think I am loyal to Spigen now. They really seem to know what they're doing. At a fraction of the price no less.

Let me first start off that I've been with the iPhone since its inception, and in that time I've been through literally dozens of brands from Incase, OtterBox, etc., to even Lifeproof cases. I chose the Element Case Solace because when I saw my buddy have on his iPhone it looked VERY sexy and most of all I loved the sleekness of the case. Obviously it was much more expensive than your 95% of the cases out there, but i thought it was possibly the material was sturdier so it would justify the price.

WRONG!!

I've only had it for a little over a month, and one particular day I accidentally bumped it off a dinner table and it hit the kitchen floor.  When I picked it up, it had a clean break near the corner of the case. ABSOLUTELY WORTHLESS now, $80 down the drain. I've even tried to salvage with super glue, gorilla glue, and in desperation, freaking epoxy; and every time it NEVER holds.

I know many of you, like myself, "baby" our phones; don't put keys with it in our pockets, handle it carefully while standing up, etc. but accidents WILL happen, and you would like your case to at least survive on more than one accident or fall. Isn't that why we bought a case in the first place! I have never been let down this badly on paying for a iPhone case ever. I might as well go back to the LifeProof case; its the same price and I KNOW I can torture it!

Fail on you Element! I gave it two stars because admittedly, when it was intact, I got a lot of ooohs and aahs from friends and family, but after one drop, now I gotta go back and tell them not to get it!

If you're reading this now, and you're still convinced you still want to buy it, BUYER BEWARE, because it is a $80 fragile case. Sheesh.
summary: WARNING: CASE EASILY BREAKS! $80 down the tube in one month!!

reviewText: I really did a lot of research on a band for my Apple Watch and after reading countless reviews I took the plunge for this one.  The fit and finish was ok but not great.  What others have said about seeing unpainted silver between the links is true.  Especially if you resize it to fit smaller wrists like mine.  The latch works ok but is not black like the rest of the band.  I tried many different configurations with more links on one side than the other and vise versa but could just not get a comfortable fit.  It was either too tight or too loose and if it was too loose it was too stiff and just did not feel right.  Some of the links seem to move nice and free,  others seem stiff.  Makes me wonder what the real Apple bracelet feels like for hundreds more??  If its anything like this one,  which it might be given its the same kind of design I cant imagine its any more comfortable.  I really liked the style and the fact the connectors are part of the bracelet and not just some "bar" that other brands of watch bands use but its just not comfortable for me (small wrists) and for the money I expected better.  I'm returning it and going for a more traditional style watch bracelet that can be resized smaller and still be comfortable at the expense of having those nicer connectors that this one offers. .
summary: I really wanted to like this band

reviewText: OEM!

This is a strong, elegant case. Glides on and fits evenly and snugly, some may even feel it fits too snugly. The benefit of the snug fit is that helps prevent most dirt from getting under the case to be ground into and scratch the finish of your phone. There is also a velvet pad on the inside back of the upper and lower pieces that keeps the case itself from scratching the phone.

This case is slim enough to fit into a holster and its matte finish makes it easier to grab and comfortable to hold. I can also say, from experience, the case also protects the phone impacts if dropped while the finish of the case remains pretty durable. Please note: I can say this even after (clumsily and most embarrassingly) dropping my phone on tile, concrete and asphalt.

The only negative I could see is that this case was nearly impossible to remove initially and is still TRULY difficult to remove. This, however, is not much of a problem if you do not use a dock. I remove my case only to clean my phone because I use a cable to charge and sync. Even video cables (Apple branded and generic composite cables) work well with this case. I am actually considering buying a second of another color...

(Also note that generic video cables no longer work with the iPhone after OS upgrade 3.0, but that is another review...)

I am using this on my 2008 Lexus IS250 since it only has bluetooth for talking on the phone and not playing music. The quality sounds very nice on this without any distortion and i love how i am also able to answer calls on this.

reviewText: So: you scored yourself a shiny new HTC EVO 4G, and laid down something between $179 and $499, depending on who sold you the hardware and the state of your contract. As you closed the deal, your provider offered a monthly insurance plan and you started doing the math, adding up the total for your new data plan, the monthly fee for 4G services, and everything else that comes along as you adopt "convergence". If, like me, you rolled the dice and passed on the insurance, this can offer a modest bit of piece of mind. It fits nicely around the Evo, while offering easy access to all display surfaces, the four soft keys, data ports, camera, speaker and kickstand. A thin rubber membrane covers the side volume keys and top power button; the membrane has raised areas providing tactile feedback on the location of those controls, which still work normally through the cover. Will this protect your Evo from everything that comes its way? Not a chance. Will it keep it from an uncontrolled slide off your car seat or table top? Probably so. Will the thin rubber rim save your screen from some scratches. Almost certainly. The "fishbone" name comes from nice combination of colors contrasting the hard and soft plastic sections. One minor gripe to keep this from 5 stars: The bottom rubber piece (between the four soft keys and HDMI/USB ports could have benefited from some reinforcing to make it stiffer; it flexes easily as you slide your fingers around those keys. Not a serious flaw, and I liked this case enough to buy a second one in Red for the other Evo user at home. It won't save your Evo from total mayhem...but might buy you one more careless moment:-)

Glass screen protector's quality is excellent. But what is notable about this product are the two clear flaps situated on its top and bottom portions. These flaps make the installation process both easy and intuitive. Will definitely get this item again.
summary: One of the easiest glass screen protectors to install.

reviewText:
I've been using (and reviewing) headsets on and off for several years.

I like the fit. It's not too big, and it's not too small.

Out of the box it was already charged, which is a huge benefit for me. I appreciate that.

It uses a regular USB charging port, which means that any of my (numerous) chargers will charge this thing.

It's easy to pair with your smartphone and it's easy to use. At first I didn't realize there were "buttons" on the unit itself, and was wondering how it would work. Well, the buttons are in just the right place to make it easy to start and end conversations. And saying "yes" (to answer the call) and "no" (to ignore the call) really do work.

Obviously having a conversation is not as easy to have when you're talking directly into your phone, but the other party seems to be able to hear me pretty well, not perfectly, but pretty well.

It does hold a good charge. I don't wait until the battery is low before charging it again (maybe I should?), because I'm always afraid to be in a situation in which I need it and can't use it, but I can certainly go a week without charging it.

If you want a rugged case then the New Trent Trentius Ultra-thin Rugged Case is for you, it is a great product for the Galaxy S5.  This is a very sturdy case and the option to change colors is great.
The USB charging port is easily accessible, as well as the headphone port, which has a nice cover to keep debris out.
I am in the construction field and I have dropped the phone a few times, and it has survived without any issues thanks to this case. I really love the sturdiness and functionality of this case.
Another thing I like is the case adds some grip to the phone. Without a case the phone is real slick and easily can slide out of your hand, already has for me a couple of times when I first received it, but with the rubber border of the rugged case it makes it easier to hold.
The cover on the back does not interfere with the camera like some cases do and the flash and heart rate monitor are also easily accessed. The cover over the speakers does protect it little better but seems to muffle the sound very slightly.
The cover is very easy to install on the phone and fits securely, yet is not impossible to remove if needed.
The built in screen protector does slightly alter the touch, which I really like because the S5s screen is very sensitive, almost too sensitive, so for me the phone works flawlessly in the case.
Lastly I will mention that I had placed a Qi Charging tab under the original Samsung back cover when I first purchased the phone, as I did not like opening the USB cover all the time, and I was worried that the rugged cover may interfere with the ability to charge, and I am happy to say that there is not any issue, it charges as well with the Trentius cover in place as without the cover.
Buy it, and be happily protected.
Pros-
Stylish for a full cover
rigid / slim protection
colored changeable back plates
screen protector is fingerprint friendly

Cons-
Dust collection under screen cover - but easy to clean
summary: Rugger Ultra-Thin Case, another Excellent Quality Product from New Trent

reviewText:
Okay--right up front, I'll admit it: I have been a die-hard Palm OS addict since I first purchased one of their (ancient) organizers back in the day. I resisted switching to another brand for a slew of reasons, none of which were all that valid--at least not when I look back on it now. The Palm platform was nothing if not user-friendly...I've said it before: those who designed the Palm OS simply must have assumed it would be used by simpletons who were barely above the deep-thinking of your average Neanderthal. My wife & daughter both have Blackberry Curves, and after playing with them on and off, I further refused to consider anything other than Palm because I couldn't figure it out all that quickly. But things change...but I certainly did NOT want to, I can assure you that.

About 6-8 months ago, my Palm 755p began giving me trouble. It wasn't very frequent--at first...but after a few weeks of spontaneous re-starts, some at the most unwanted times, I really began to become annoyed. Working in radio, I did a live broadcast remote at a wireless location and started to seriously consider a Windows Mobile phone (in this case, it was a Moto Q9c). I began to slowly research the Moto Q and Windows Mobile phones in particular on the web and also here at amazon.com. What I discovered was other than a select few, the majority of reviews from Windows users were by and large disappointed with their phones. The common thread wasn't the quality of the phones, but the stability of the Operating System itself.

This lead me to consider Blackberry...reluctantly, but a kernal of hope took root and before long, my Treo's problems put me on the fast track to getting a phone that only months before I had vowed never to purchase. I would've loved to get another Palm, but having played with the Centro, I found the keyboard actually TOO small for me to comfortably use--and I don't have big fingers, so I think that says a lot right there. I considered a Windows phone made by Palm, but gave up after reading way too many complaints about the OS screwing up way too much. The upcoming Palm Pre looks VERY promising, but my Treo simply wasn't going to last long enough, so I took the plunge.

The Bold is out of the box, striking. It's wider than my Treo but MAN is it thinner by a rather large amount--nearly half I'd say.  The keyboard is quite a bit different in several ways...let me explain: some of the icons and symbols are in entirely different locations than what I had become used to with my Treo 650, 700p and subsequent 755p. I thought it would take FOREVER to get used to that, but surprisingly it didn't at all. Also, the keyboard takes advantage of the wider real estate and is spread out further...but the REAL difference (IMO) is my Palm keys were more individual and separated and way higher than on the Bold. Now THIS took some getting used to. On my Palm it was rather easy, even without looking to move my fingers from one key to the next and simply know from that touch alone that I was on a different key. This is not the case with the Bold keyboard. It bothered me--at first, but after a few days, I have become attuned to the difference and it no longer bothers me like it initially did.

The next major change is the screen...and boy is this a mighty HUGE change. First off, I have become rather accustomed to using a touch-screen now for quite some time...it was one of my biggest problems with switching to Blackberry. I briefly considered the Storm, but after playing with the virtual keyboard, I ruled that out entirely. I MUST have a keyboard--the virtual one's just don't cut it for me. The other thing is the 100% Upgrade the screen turned out to be compared with the Treo. I've read about it quite a bit and I gotta tell you, until you see it yourself, words almost cannot do it justice. This screen is unbelievably brilliant. Frickin' incredible. It's a bit wider and a tad shorter than my Palm but the display certainly looked 2 to 3 times brighter and way more clear. Off the charts a MUCH better screen. I have yet to see its equal. I cannot tell you how many times I went--out of habit--to grab the stylus in order to tap it on the screen only to realize my phone no longer has one. I hear rumor that RIM is coming out with a Bold-like phone with a keyboard and touch screen...now THAT will be a phone to look out for...but back to my Bold...

I'll be honest, it is quite a change switching to an Operating System so dramatically different than the moronically simple one employed by Palm. Breaking old habits seem to be harder the older I get. Where Palm was intuitive and just plain obvious, Blackberry has been difficult and almost imposible to figure out. I chalk this up to my stubborness more than anything else...but the fact remains: the OS of my Blackberry suffers in comparison to how ridiculously easy Palm phones are to use and figure out. While I am STILL working on getting used to my phone, it DOES have some nifty features NOT found in any Palm device (yet)...for instance, the one thing that sets Blackberry's apart from EVERYTHING else out there is e-mail. This certainly is one place where the Bold not only beats Palm, but embarasses it entirely. The set-up was easy enough that even my Grandma could figure it out and within less than 10 minutes, I had 4 separate e-mail accounts up and running without a hitch. Too easy and it is definitely where the Bold shines (other than the screen).

The trackball also takes some getting used to. It's nice that you can adjust the sensitivity of the ball, (much like using a mouse) so if you like to scroll quickly, you can, or if you'd like a bit more control, don't worry, you can do that, too. Another place where the Bold wins hands down is the speaker. It actually has TWO separate speakers which delivers actual stereo sound, quite loudly, I might add. Another really nifty thing if you ask me. It paired up with my Bluetooth quite easily and the sound quality from what those on the other end have told me is noticeably better than on my Palm (which was notorious for having Bluetooth issues).

One thing I honestly wish Blackberry did differently is allow the phone to ring and vibrate at the same time. I always figured my wife just couldn't figure it out herself for why her's never did...but as it turns out the phone will vibrate first, and THEN ring. You cannot switch it to do both simultaneously...why, I simply have no clue. The addition of WiFi is a nice added bonus. At work I can surf using the wireless network at my office, also at home and at several friends houses out in the country where service is spotty. Another major advantage over Palm...although in fairness many newer Palms have built-in WiFi...but NONE of the models I have used ever did. 3G service is pretty nice, too...but my Treo 700p and 755p were both EVDO equipped, which are essentially the same thing, so no big difference there. Downloading websites and attachments via email online is a breeze.

A couple places where Blackberry can take a cue from Palm (and I realize there aren't that many) are the lack of a switch on the outside that allows you to turn off the ringer instantly without using the screen. I also wish the button to turn on the speaker during a call was situated on the screen and activated via the trackball rather than having to push the tiny $ key on front...it just seems a bit harder to find, even in the dark with the backlight on. A small annoyance, but a valid one all the same.

While I have heard many complain about the clarity of the camera, I gotta tell you its WAY better than the measly 1.3 mega-pixel standard on the Palms I've used. I snapped a photo of my little son and sent it to my wife's Blackberry Curve and she wrote back wondering where I had got the photo never once considering it had come from my phone. Sure it'd be nice to have a 3.2 mp camera like on the Storm and 8900, but all in all I am satisfied--especially having come from the inferior Treo camera. The video recorder is noticeably of less quality than the camera is, which strikes me a little odd, but I don't usually videotape much using my phone, so I don't really see that to be a problem for me--but you never know.

All in all, I gotta admit--and while it was a LONG time in coming, the Blackberry has won me over. The lack of almost ANY advance in the Palm OS over the course of over 10 years is pretty inexcusable if you ask me. Seriously, my original Palm organizer (no phone) looks relatively unchanged (other than color vs monochrome) from my old Treo 755p. Sure there are a few cosmetic changes in that time, but overall, the OS looks essentially exactly the same as it did from the beginning. That certainly made it easy to figure out when you upgraded over your previous model, but come ON...really? That is much too long to hold onto an outdated OS. The upcoming Pre certainly looks way cool and is an obvious 100% upgrade on the OS, but it just may be a little too late for some--it certainly was for me.

If you are a die-hard Palm user frantically becoming disillusioned with your phone, its time to seriously consider moving on and putting the old away in exchange for something enirely new...just be prepared to take a while to get used to it...knowing that alone will make the conversion much easier to handle.

Kudos to Blackberry on such a fine product. Conversion complete.

*****UPDATE*****

I am STILL working on getting used to Blackberry's entirely different Operating System. I find myself continually reaching for a stylus that isn't there, but I am slowly adjusting to a non-touch-screen phone (emphasis on s-l-o-w-l-y).

The battery...? Well, let's just say as long as you have WiFi turned off, it's reasonably okay...which is to say on par with my Treo 755p...well, maybe a shade better, but not by much.

The trackball...? Surfing on the Web using the trackball is MUCH less efficient than being able to use a stylus (or my finger). I find when I want to scroll down to the bottom of a particularly large page, it can seem like forever having to scroll down so slowly. I wish it were differently--and who knows? Maybe there is a work-around that I am unaware of...

The e-mail set up and usage is simply FIRST RATE I have to admit. I haven't bothered to check my e-mail using my computer in several weeks now because I simply don't NEED to. I still send e-mail using my computer because even with the QWERTY keyboard, actually writing a message is still easier using a regular-sized keyboard...but I do find myself not even trying to access e-mail online much...thanks Bold!

WiFi IS VERY convenient! The only minor gripe I have is that when I am in an area with less than stellar AT&T coverage, I turn on WiFi and the phone STILL tries to use the almost non-existent signal to go online. I naturally assumed that the phone would use the strongest signal available, but as it turns out, that isn't the case. Now that I have that figured out, it's simply a case of figuring out where my signal strengths are and remember to turn off and on WiFi and phone receiver. Yes, it IS a bit of a problem, but my Alltel 755p had poor reception where my bedroom is and I was plain SOL if I wanted to check something online--at least NOW I have an option, however inconvenient it may be (I assure you, this is a minor gripe at best).

The mp3 player is incredibly easy to use--unfortunately the built-in equalizer isn't all that great and the volume isn't quite what I'd like it to be--but seeing as I have managed to mis-place (lost) my Sansa Clip mp3 player, this is at least a nice alternative that otherwise wasn't available.

I downloaded Transformers and Eagle Eye recently and I MUST say, this is yet one more place where the stunning screen simply SHINES beyond the competition. Add to that the fantastic stereo speakers, and watching feature-length movies in the palm of my hand couldn't be more cool & simple.

I DO wish the button to turn on the speakerphone was a bit easier to locate and turn on...once again, adding a button to access the speaker ON the screen with the trackball, well that would be a giant leap forward for this device if you ask me.

I am still finding it difficult to access a couple of books I downloaded using Mobi Pocket (ie I cannot access them at all), but otherwise, I am still impressed and VERY happy.
summary: Former Palm user Free @Last with Blackberry conversion

I've been using wet application screen protectors for a couple years now. They are so much better than the dry application kind... when I first started using them, I was very careful about the liquid and dust/lint, etc... after having applied several sets of these to various phones and tablets over the years, I have become pretty cavalier about the application process.  I wash my hands with soap and water, do a few pumps of the liquid on my fingers that Skinomi includes, then a couple pumps on the phone and a couple more on the protector.  Then I peel off the protector from it's backing, slap it on the phone and align it just right.  Bring the the squeegee and squeegee off the excess water, trying to mostly avoid the holes (earpiece, etc...) in the phone and then dry it off with a cloth.

I then let the phone sit over night still turned off and it's ready to go in the morning.  The screen looks pretty bad for the first 24 - 48 hours, but once all the liquid evaporates through the protector materiel, it is usually clear as glass and I've not yet had any real problem with dust.  If I had a complaint about wet application protectors is that they don't feel nearly as nice as glass and some dry application protectors.  This is really a minor quibble, but the rubbery material that these Skinomi protectors are made of kind of drags on the finger when you are sliding around the screen.  It's not bad, but not nearly as kinesthetically pleasing as sliding around the glass.  As I said, it's a minor quibble on an otherwise excellent product.  The fit on the Nexus 5 is spot on - I was a little concerned that it did not have cutouts for the light sensor and mass sensors (but it does for the speaker), but it doesn't seem to affect the performance of either sensor, so I guess they aren't necessary.

Overall, an excellent product and I heartily recommend these to anyone looking for a screen protector.  Don't let the wet application scare you away, it's not really that hard and the fit and finish of the final product once installed is vastly superior to any dry application screen protector I have ever used (and I've used plenty!).

The fairly thick instruction manual is only thick because it is in many languages, the instructions are really only two pages long (plus one page of diagram).  The *key* instruction is to download the app *before* you connect your phone to the device.  The app provides much more detailed actual instructions on how to use the device.

As an extra battery / portable charging device this is great (but a bit large and heavy) and easy to use (just plug your phone in).  As additional memory it is definitely more dubious.

Good: backing up contacts is trivially simple.

Poor: The device seems to work okay with photos, but music seems to be completely differently handled.  I watched my 28 year old daughter be completely baffled by the user interface.  The first stumbling block was that she didn't realize she had to "wake up" the device (not just turn it on) before the phone would see it.  She could not find a way to transfer music from the phone to the device.  It seems the device is really only intended as supplemental storage and thus you add more music from your PC and then it is available to be played from the Imation Link.

Keep in mind this is for iPhone 5s and 6s and not the 4 or before.  (and won't work with an Android phone)

This is actually the second one of these I bought.  When the iPhone 6 first came out I wanted a thin, lightweight cover to protect against scratches and daily use.  I really liked the Apple Leather one but couldn't bring myself to spend the money.  I bought a blue one of these and have been absolutely thrilled with it. Note that the top and bottom are exposed (which I like) so this is not a rough and tumble camping case.  I've dropped my phone a few times but indoors, typically on a carpet and this has been fine.  Dropping it outside on a driveway would probably end up with a different story.

The case is wonderfully lightweight and thin, looks great on the phone, and gets rid of the insanely slippery nature of the 6 / 6s.  The volume and power buttons are covered but easy to use, the mute toggle is exposed.  After about a year the corners of the case have worn enough from daily use that I decided to splurge and buy a replacement one - I looked through my order history to figure out what I had purchased originally to make sure I got another one - different color, this time with an opening for the Apple Logo, but same case.  Highly recommend.
summary: Great lightweight, casual protection case - lasts about a year of daily use.  Won't save from outside hard falls.

reviewText:
I only bought mine for $118 but I can't believe all the features this phone has packed in,

it has a nice screen it's big and bright but a a little hard to see outdoors or and bright light it areas, screen reflector scratch protector helps with that.

4G LTE connectivity this is a very nice feature, but you need to be on a compatible plan and service in order to use this

battery life now this is what I've got to be a bit of a downer but battery life is very short especially the use LTE for long periods of time or play games to me it just falls short, so far with the light usage I can get about 4 to 5 hours, but using LTE and playing games for long periods of time I can only get about 3 hours of use out of it.

it's also got real GPS built in most phones don't have this they have a GPS but this GPS works by using satellites even if you're out of range of your wireless carrier you have a special app you can have GPS assistance without any wireless signal from your carrier, and of course it also has network-based locations which needs your wireless signal for that.

its got Bluetooth I've use my bluetooth stereo headphones and they found is good luck with my last phone but I don't see any difference in the Bluetooth

the wifi is standard at 802.11 n. and it only supports Wifi in the 2.4 gigahertz range.

the cameras a bit disappointing and the front one is a bit of a disaster I haven't played around with them for a long. Of time but the front camera can be used for video chatting great for taking selfies but it blurry in the back camera is not super crystal clear light I guess I want it to be, but I'll continue to play around with the settings to see if I can get it any better.

its comes ship with an old outdated version of Android, but mine was already upgraded to Ice Cream Sandwich if yours comes with the older version you can download the Ice Cream Sandwich upgrade from Pantech website.

well that's it for now after I've had the phone for a week or two maybe a month or write a more detailed review explaining the features and problems that may have cared.

but overall I'm very excited to have the phone
summary: A smart phone without the smartphone price

I bought this phone as an upgrade to my Dash4.5, that was beginning to slow down under the pressure of ever-demanding applications. I was hoping to upgrade from the Dash Antutu index of 7k to the impressive Life Antutu index of 26k.  The specs of this phone were definitely an upgrade, but the phone itself was somewhat of a disappointment.

The Positives - The screen is crisp and viewable from most angles.  The processing power is pretty good, although the speed is not blazing, as the specs would indicate.  The music player is very good, particularly if you use a high-quality headset instead of the speaker or the stock headset.  The GPS is responsive, and the download speed is fast, although not blazing.  The phone connects to TMobile 3G very comfortably  The camera is quirky, but pretty good.  It might take a while to learn all of the features of the phone, since the settings and instructions are not entirely clear.  The battery lasts more than 24 hours with medium use.  The phone is pleasantly thin and light.  The included case is a nice touch.

The Negatives  The extra strip at the bottom is very annoying, aesthetically and operationally. The screen rotation does not always work, and sometimes it is sluggish; although most of the time it is pretty quick.  The phone drops the connection frequently  sometimes it drops the connection with a SIM card not found message.  The BlueTooth feature either does not work or does not work properly, I am not sure which.
summary: Could be great, although mine was not

reviewText:
It seems like everything these days takes a Micro USB to charge them. From cell phones to tablets almost all of us has at least one item that takes this type of cable, but what about those times where you need a quick charge? A power bank is a great option that I recommend having with you at all times, but then you have to deal with lugging not only the power bank, but also an exceedingly long USB cord around all day. It can be hard to find a Micro USB cable that is not only short but offers a good charge speed ensuring you aren't stuck at the end of a power bank for hours at a time. Luckily, PowerBot created a small yet capable device that pairs perfectly with a power bank.

The PowerBot PB302 is actually quite surprisingly small, at only about 6 inches it takes up little to no space in the packaging it comes in. The packaging itself is done very well, so well as a matter of fact, that it can actually be hard to take out of the packaging! The cardboard packaging keeps the cord snug in its plastic encasing. Once opened, (a tough but do-able job) I was caught a bit off guard. I was expecting something a bit stiff, that would keep its position once used. Once I got my hands on it I noticed an almost gelatinous movement when held. This is a positive for people who would like this to be as portable as possible, as you do not need to worry about this mechanism breaking over time.

Since I had the PowerBot 7 port charger, I decided to give the SB302 a try by charging my tablet (An Asus 7 inch tablet). It worked well and I did get the full benefit from the cord as the charging speed came in at right around 2 amps. This number will, however, change depending on the quality of your charger. Most power banks will charge your phone at a half of an amp, so this method will take considerably longer no matter what you choose as your USB cord of choice.

Fortunately, the PowerBot PB302 is also a sync cable; meaning this can transfer files from your phone to your PC and vice versa. I do not see myself using this method too much in the future, the transfer speed was great, but a long cable is infinitely more comfortable to use when transferring files from a large PC.

Overall, the PowerBot PB302 is a great choice as a Micro USB cable for a power bank. It can be twisted, tied, and blatantly thrown about at will without worry because of the high-quality rubber it is made out of, the USB and Micro USB ports are also of high quality with little-to-no wiggle room inside of its encasing. However, if you are like me who charges your phone every night and does not need a small USB cable for a power bank, I do not see the practicality of this USB cable. If you are a person who needs a quick boost every now and again, I would advise you to check this PowerBot PB302 out on Amazon as it will not only save you time when it is needed but also money when it comes to choosing the right USB cable for your needs.

 I received this item at a discount in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.
summary: The PowerBot PB302 is a great choice as a Micro USB cable for a power bank

Updated:  Noot sent a free replacement. On the new one, the fast charge works on my LG G5, so changing my review.

Original:  On either port the fast charge does not work. Is this yet another LG G5 problem? Or the charger? I will never know.

If you are the type who is reasonably careful with your phone, this really is the perfect case. This is a better-than-nothing level of protection, mostly to prevent scrapes and gouges from a drop. It does offer protection, but probably the least amount you can get with a case. There is no gel inner layer, so it is basically like having a stock phone with a really think back plate. So if you are the clumsy type prone to dropping your phone, I'd suggest going with a case a little more robust. There is a lip that raises the display off the surface from the sides, but you can still see the rounded edges of the display, and it looks really cool. Camera port, Mic ports, charge port, and headphone jacks are all easily accessed. Though it doesn't offer a heavy amount of protection, it's not as necessary on the Nexus 6, since Motorola did an awesome job making the phone hard to break.

I absolutely love the soft touch plastic, which is similar to the covering on the Nexus 5 and Nexus 7. It cleans easily, is resistant to fingerprints, and is much more grippy than the stock coating or other hard cases. Really, this is how the case of the phone itself should feel, and the phone looks better with this case on and is a pleasure to hold. I love the minimalistic and high tech look it imparts to the phone. I could have done without the Spigen logo on the back, but at least it is also in black. I love that it adds very little bulk and weight to the device.

I used this same model case on my Nexus 5 for over a year. It took a bullet for my phone several times, at least 3 or 4 times I dropped it. My Nexus 5 display never shattered, and even today looks to be in mint condition thanks to the case. Even when it is dropped, it takes a lot to actually damage the plastic. Cuts and gouges are still hard to spot because of the matte look of it.
summary: Still the best Case you can get for a Nexus

I am pretty sure this is an authentic product in non-retail packaging.  My husband bought these to replace the ones that came with our Galaxy S5 phones.  We needed to replace them because the cats promptly chewed them up (we do not have this problem with any of our other cords or cables).  If the Samsung logo wasn't enough to convince me of the authenticity of this product, the fact that the cats chewed these immediately lends credence to their veracity.  I don't know what it is about the coating, but 2 out of 3 cats can not resist it.  We tried spraying the cords with bitter cherry, that worked for a day or two. The only real solution has been covering their entire length with electrical tape or use a different cable.  Thus far none of the cats have been visibly harmed, but they have chewed completely through these cords.

This is a perfect replacement for any S-5 owner.  The product description says that they will will fully charge the phone in about 3 hours.  I find that mine can go for 2% to 100% in about an hour.  It's really kind of awesome because charging my old S3 seemed to take forever.  These are not a universal cable.  They will no work with the S3 or any other device with a standard Micro USB input.  I find the 5-foot cable to be a perfect length.  I use my phone as an alarm clock, so there's plenty of room to go from the outlet to the night stand.

(Pro Tip: If for some reason you are hospitalized, ask the nurse for a piece of tape.  Tape your charger to your bedside table with a little bit of a tail.  You'll be much happier, and the nurses will think you're a genius.)

I would buy these again in a heartbeat, but alas- I'm afraid of electrocuting the cats.  I only put these in the car, which doesn't have quite as great of an impact.  Also, I can't use this cable when I use my FM Transmitter.  There's way too much engine whine.  I highly recommend this product to anyone who doesn't have Samsung-cord-seeking cats.  Unfortunately, I'm going to have to go with an aftermarket ribbon-cable product.

At the time I invested in LUVVITT CRISTAL Hard Shell Anti-Scratch Transparent Case for iPhone 5 (LIFETIME WARRANTY | Retail Packaging) - Crystal Clear, but was disappointed. My biggest disappointments were that the manufacturer charged a hefty price (due to lack of limited options) and no screen protector was included. Amazon did it again by getting the price, the design and accessories spot on! For $10 you get a clear case with a screen protector that provides a slight ridge for the front edges of the phone, which prevent it from being scratched when it falls. reviewText:
A little hard to install without bubbles on the edges. I've installed dozens of screen protectors on all sort of devices and these tend to want to peel if you get them too close to the edge, which is difficult to avoid because they're cut so precisely. That precision is a good thing, don't get me wrong, but the adhesive layer could be just a bit thicker.

That said, if you put forth the effort to get this thing installed just right, the texture is great and doesn't grab your finger as you swipe across it, and it makes the display look absolutely stunning.
summary: difficult to install, but worth the effort

I ordered this, on a Saturday, received it on a Wednesday!
The reason I ordered it, was because another "flagship killer" was unable to produce enough fo their "killer" phones to meet demand.
Very high quality packaging, arrived in good condition.  Turning it on, the battery was at 46%.  I just set it up using wi-fi, synced my
apps, set up email etc without issue.  I don't know what people are worrying about, with it "only" being a 720p screen, it looks fantastic
sitting next to my now retired Galaxy note1.  The size is NOT that bad either.  Spec wise, my note1 and this are pretty much the
same width & thickness, and only around 1/2" longer, but, with those reduced bezels on the Mate2, that gives me 8/10th of an inch
MORE screen size!  Screen is bright & clear, no bad pixels.  I shaved my standard size sim card down to fit it, came right up in H+
mode (shows 4g on the display).  Need to stop by Walmart (I'm on straight talk) and get a new sim so the LTE light will come on.
I use bluetooth, and never the handset microphone or speaker, bluetooth is CRYSTAL clear, better than my note.  The ring, sounds and other speaker sound is VERY loud.  This one came with 4.3, which isn't a deal killer for me, it's an upgrade from 4.1.2 that I was using.
I don't use the built in launcher, but opt for Nova since that is what I'm use to.
Now, for that HUGE battery!  Left this morning at 100% charged.  After a couple hours of phone usage, few dozen emails, web surfing, text messaging, I still have around 90% left!  It might take me a few days just to run the battery down, which is one of the main reasons I got this.
I hate running out of juice.
The camera, has some nifty features and the image quality is top notch.  The built in software is pretty good, but I'm use to Camera FV-5, and the macro mode works pretty darn good!
Huawei hit one out of the park, in my opinion.  If you like big screens, you'll love this!

Update, still going strong over a year after purchase.  Huawei did update the device late June 2015, to LL5.1, and also provided an easy way to go back to JB4.3 if you didn't like it.  First version of LL does have a couple minor bugs.  If you switch the launcher, text messaging etc, from the default to a 3rd party app, once you power off/on, it goes back to the Mate2 default apps.  If you are like me and never turn your device off, it's no big deal.  The other minor bug is they need to tweak it a bit.  It is using just a little more battery than before, but nothing that impacts that 2 day battery life.  If I had to do it all over again, I would STILL get this phone, it's a winner!

I installed this in a 40' x 40' metal shop that was blocking cell signals. I now have great coverage throughout the shop that has two rooms and a large open area. It even provided better cell coverage outside the building. It is a little expensive but it does work.

I am very happy with my purchase. This product is exactly as it was described. It is very light, the purple color I chose is gorgeous, the fit is perfection and I don't feel scared to death I am going to scratch my phone or break the case when removing it. It is not a cover that will offer much protection if the phone is dropped and lands face down, but I'm convinced the damage should be less than it would be without it. This cover allows me to still enjoy the beauty of the phone itself.

This is a smashingly beautiful phone. I have the champagne gold and it is luxurious. In hand it feels comfortable, not too large and not heavy, but no featherweight.  It is sleek; its design is outstanding. I upgraded from an HTC Desire HD and glad I stayed with HTC; it makes using the HTC One much easier.  The phone arrived in the proprietary box, sealed. Inside was the phone, ac/usb adapter/charger; pin to assist in opening SIM and SD card. The only thing missing was a manual but HTC has a pdf file online which gives all the information.  I had read in some forums that music could not be  put on the SD card and played. This is untrue. I put 4 GIG of music on my SDXC 64g and played all night. It does not have to be on internal storage.  The stereo boom speakers are outstanding, with pure reproduction of whatever you choose to play. The front and main cameras work very nicely and many extras can be added (if desired) to the image. Actually, it's just like having a point and shoot camera and its multiple options inside your phone. I'm impressed with the quality of images I've taken and those moved to the One from my computer and viewed.  All in all, I'm thrilled that I made this purchase and am certain I'll learn more tricks as time goes on. I'll edit if anything changes. Bravo, HTC!

reviewText:
Intrigued by this product once I read about it in the NY Times, I ordered a Raspberry Pi along with the guide written by the co-founder of the Foundation.  In retrospect, I should have also bought the SD card that comes pre-loaded with an Operating System (OS) because I spent numerous hours trying to create my own SD card, first using a Windows PC.  When that failed, I tried on a MAC.  No success either.

I understand and accept that this product is for tinkerers so I do not regret all the time spent.  However, I did not expect to have to be an experienced "geek" with basic understanding of the DOS commands to create the SD card.  I guess this is exactly the goal of the Raspberry Pi: get people to learn the inside workings of a basic computer.

So I reluctantly returned the product.  Yes, I could have purchased the preloaded SD card but my sense of pride got in the way.  I swallowed that pride and concluded that, if I could not get started with booting properly, I was not destined to do much with the Pi afterwards.
summary: I give it a neutral 3 stars because I was not able to test potential.  Get the preloaded SD card!

While this gives you the same level of scratch protection as the products designed for larger devices, this product has a tendency of peeling off too easily.  That might explain why you get many in one box.

1ST INSTALLATION:
My initial install went well, except I didn't allow the material the "cure" long enough to allow the film to dry smooth across the screen.  This wasn't a big deal to me considering I had extras to try again later.

After going out one night, I came home and discovered the film had come off completely while I was out and hadn't realized it.

2ND INSTALLATION:
For the 2nd time, I applied the film again, this time much more successfully.  I gave myself a couple of days to allow the film to dry and cure without powering the watch back on to ensure the best result.  This time, the film looked much better than the 1st attempt-- smoother finish, no bubbles or peeled up corners.

Unfortunately about a week later, I noticed a corner starting to peel up. After a day or two, I just peeled it off completely and have not applied a replacement film since.

I think the problem with this product is the inability to strongly adhere to the rounded edges of the watch screen.  Couple that with the amount of unintended contact the watch face has with the outside environment and that will lead to having to replace it more frequently than you might imagine.

I enjoy Skinomi's products, but I wouldn't necessarily worry about getting this product for your Apple Watch.

That's not really a deal-breaker for me because I only see that when I take the laptop off the cooling pad, but it is a bit gross.

But how does it perform?  Reasonably well, much better once I got a laptop case that has little tabs that prop up the back of the laptop for better ventilation.

I love this case.  Feels great in the hand, and "dat silicone" in the corners.  I actually like to bounce the phone on the corners (1-2" drops, nothing that would be considered a drop).  It has a nice little bounce.  This is my third SG case, and all of them have been awesome.  Fit and finish is perfect.  I used the screen protector for a few weeks, but didn't like the haze it put on the screen, and kind of made the screen look like an oil slick in the rain.  The case does add a fair amount of bulk, so if you prefer a minimalistic case, this is not the case for you.  If you want the ultimate in protection for your phone, this is it.  I never used the holster that came with it, but it did seem durable, and well made.  If you are a holster user, you won't be disappointed.  If you put the phone in your pocket with the screen facing your leg, you will end up pulling your pocket inside out.  If you put it in your pocket with the screen facing out, it's much better.  Still tugs at the pocket a little, but nowhere near as much.

The only complaint I'll make about this case, which prevents a 5 star review, are the silicone flaps over the charge port, and headphone jack.  They don't stay closed very well, and stick out a little from the case.  If you have a bad case of OCD, you will end up going crazy seeing that (my OCD is very minor, so I can just let it ride).
summary: Works great - but one nagging OCD-type issue

I purchased an LG Power for use on Straight Talk a few weeks ago.  Looking in the store where I was purchasing the phone, I couldn't find any cases, so I jumped online and found quite a selection.  Granted, many of the cases that you find are of one particular design or style with several different colors or printed designs on them to choose from.  I wanted a case that was sleek, without a belt clip, that would offer a decent level of protection.  I think I found it with this purchase.  The rubber sleeve fits the phone perfectly, and the snap on, 2 piece front and back cover has a nice gunmetal gray color to it.  The outer case snaps on easily and fits snug.  You have access to all ports on the phone and cutouts on the rear that offer protection but don't limit mobility.  I really can't complain about what this case can offer you, especially for the $10 or under price you can currently purchase it.  It also included a free stylus and screen cover, but I'm not using either as I had already purchased a cover for this phone but hey, I won't turn down any free extras.  When I showed my wife the cover after putting it on the phone she thought I had purchased an Otterbox.  I've owned Otterbox covers before on other phones and I'd say my newest cover comes darn close to the level of protection my past Otterbox covers have offered.  One element of the design that I really enjoy is the extra space the cover occupies in your hands when you hold the phone horizontally to text.  The added thickness makes this phone even more ergonomic to use.  Overall, I am very happy with this purchase.  Final note, the cover has small indentations on the right side making the separation of the front and back covers a simple, pain-free process.
summary: If you have an LG Power, look no further for the perfect case!

I am really happy with this outlet! It works perfectly for where I installed it. Since we bought several Echo Dot devices I have been adding smart plugs and using them to voice control lights and run timers for things. I really like this hardwired outlet over the plug in type I have bought previously.

- It is much nicer to look at versus a big bulky wifi plug. (more wife-approved)
- There is no huge branding across the front. Much appreciated. Thanks!
- The Alexa voice control features respond quickly.
- I like that it has a manual button we can use if we want to.

The only thing I noticed that may be an issue is there is no place to land a second set of wires. Most outlet boxes have a romex cable coming into the box and a second cable going out to the next outlet. If that is the case where this is being installed , a pigtail would need to be used to connect this outlet to the second set of wires. In my case, I only had one cable to connect, but I know this isn't the case in the majority of my outlet boxes.
summary: Much better looking option for smart outlet control.

reviewText: I have always liked Motorola products. They are well though out, high quality and this Moto E smartphone is no exception. You will want to throw your ZTE smartphone against the wall and stomp on it after you get to use this phone. That's how good this phone is in comparison. The only downside if any is that it could have more internal memory and have a front facing camera as well. But for this price I really cant quibble. Buy an micro sd card and move as many apps to the SD card that you can to save your internal memory space. If your not going to put a lot of apps on the phone the internal memory should be sufficient for everyday use. The phone has a great response and battery life is good on a charge. The WiFi reception is far superior to the ZTE and overall cell reception is what you would expect in a cell phone. The android system is KitKat and comes with a few moto apps that come in handy. Highly recommended!
summary: Excellant upgrade for your ZTE smartphone and as a entry level smartphone

This "baby" is the same length (when fully collapsed) as my cell phone (Motorola Moto G), 5.5", but weighs less--4.89 ounces for the phone, 2.62 ounces for the selfie stick

I don't expect to see a selfie stick smaller than this one.

When you pull out the sections, the stick is 24". It takes enough effort to pull them that you feel confident it is not going to collapse until you push the sections down.

This is a one-piece selfie stick, the type I prefer; nothing to assembly, no parts to lose.

And there is no battery to charge, either. It is not Bluetooth, so it runs off the battery of your phone after plugging the cable from the selfie stick into the headphone jack of the phone.

This selfie stick is compatible with iPhone 4-6 and some Android phones. If you find it doesn't work with your phone, then download the free APP "Camera360" from Google Play. According to Google, this is the #1 APP in the photography category with more than 400 million users worldwide.

To put your phone on the stick, pull up the top of the clamp, set the phone on the "arms" on the clamp bottom and let the top down. The phone is secure. The clamp base and top are covered with soft silicone, which improves holding power and also prevents any scratching of the phone.

You can move the clamp forward and back about 270 degrees to get the angle you want for your phone. When positioned, lock it in place with a thumb screw.

When you are set up and ready to shoot your photos, just press the button on the handle of the selfie stick

As can be expected with a selfie stick so small, the handle is only 3.75".  But is covered with spongy rubber material that is very soft and non-slip.

This is a simple, well made selfie stick that is strong enough to hold phones safely. What sets it apart from other good, one-piece selfie sticks is its small size.  It is the most-pocket selfie stick available

Sample provided at a reduced price for purpose of review.
summary: "Baby" Selfie Stick; Same Length But Less Weight Than My Cell Phone

reviewText: Fast shipping. Product as described. I'm really looking forward to using this on our summer camping trips!

Update: 3 years later and I still use it a few times a week. Bought a new phone with a better battery so I don't use it as much as I used to. I see so many people searching for wall outlets all over from the mall to the coffeeshop to the library to the airport and I think to myself thank goodness I have my reliable power bank!

Honestly, it's not my first replacement power source when I'm out and about because of its weight and size because I have a spare battery I can swap out in my android phone but I prefer the power bank over a wall outlet because it's portable despite the additional weight compromises. On some occasions, I just slipped it into my back pocket with cable connected to phone in my front pants or jacket pocket. Looks bit strange but it works and more convenient.

Definitely won't leave home without it when I know I'll be out all day and especially during extended travel trips. I bought for $35 but it's seeing for $30 now and also there's a $8 coupon code! What a steal.!
summary: Like a wall outlet on the go!

I recieved this product for a fair and honest review and immediately put it on my iphone 5s.  The placement was very easy and well described in the documentation.  I made a mistake and did not clean the fingerprint scanner well before placing the cover.  After I cleaned the reader and replaced the cover, fingerprint recognition was better than it had been and better than without the cover.  It was amazing how many times it was able to recognize my fingerprint right the first time.  A huge improvement, although actually pushing the home button was a bit stiff.  I carried the phone in my front pocket and it felt no bulkier than the Speck CandyShell Flip that I used previously.  It seems to offer excellent water protection, although I did not test this capability.  I use a Belkin dock on my beside, which I was unable to use due to the data port plug being in the way.  I suppose you could cut it off and replace when not docking.  Finally, I was unable to use the Amazon charging cable with this case due to the cord's extra bulk.  The Apple cord worked great.  If you want waterproofing without bulk and the additional cost of the LifeProof case, then this one is for you!

I bought this case to protect my slippery Galaxy S7 Edge. Not only does it protect my phone from drops, it also provides a good grip on the smartphone. The built-in kickstand is very useful for watching videos or reading on a table, however, the kickstand is made of cheap plastic and doesn't seem sturdy at all. In addition, the kickstand doesn't fall flat with the rest of the case and doesn't allow the phone to lie flat. Unfortunately, the rest of the case feels cheap as well. The main body is plastic and the rubber button pushers don't even fully cover the buttons. They feel very cheap and I don't think it will last for much longer. The corners of the case also feel cheap. The corners are not rounded and are sharp and very angular. However, the absolute worst aspect of this case, even worse than the cheap feel of the case, is the fact that wireless charging, at least with Samsung's first-party wireless charger, does not work. Because of how much the kickstand juts out from the case and the thickness of the case, wireless charging does not work. Every time you go to place your Galaxy S7 Edge onto the wireless charging stand you will have to take the case off which would definitely be a deal breaker for me. While this case does will protect your phone from minor drops, the cheap build quality as well as the fact that wireless charging will not work with this case, I cannot recommend the Zizo case for the Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge.

Pros:
- Thin
- Will protect your phone from minor drops
- Kickstand

Cons:
- Cheap feel and build quality
- Not durable
- Cheap kickstand
- NO wireless charging

I just got my new Droid 3 and I use it all the time to talk, text, internet, news etc. The original 1500 mAh battery (BF5X) lasted for approximately 6h on battery saver mode, which meant I had to recharge my battery in the middle of the day. I bought this larger 1930 mAh battery to make it through the day without having to charge it. (I didn't want to buy one of those bulging batteries that stick out, so I could use my original battery cover and case) I should have known that a battery that is ca. 30% more powerful should therefore only last for 30% longer. So even with this new battery my phone only lasts for ~8h, which means I still have to charge it at least once a day.

I guess I just have to wait until my enthusiasm about this awesome new phone dies down a little and I don't drain the battery by constantly playing around with it.
summary: Does what it says, but still too little...

These screen protectors are great. You align the protector, hold it in place with rubber bands, then apply the stickers that act as hinges and remove the rubber bands, then lift up the screen protector on the hinges and clean the screen again, pull off screen protector film to expose the sticky side and lay it back down, the hinges align it perfectly. Having dust or bubbles under a screen protector drives me nuts, and it really isn't much more work than just laying it down by hand and hope it aligns properly. I highly recommend this product. They feel almost like real glass so swiping your finger on the screen is very easy.

reviewText:
OAproda iPhone 6 Plus (5.5 Inch) New Premium Tempered Glass Screen Protector

Im very happy with this glass protection shield for my iPhone 6+. It is a well packaged, in a plastic case, kit that has everything you need for a quick and easy install. It comes with a wet cleaning wipe as well as a sticky paper for dust removal and a microfiber cloth for drying and polishing. If by chance you have other phone safe cleaning solution and microfiber lint free cloths, use them too. You can never get your iPhone too clean before applying a glass screen cover.

After scrubbing down your phone you carefully position the shield over your phone and peel away the backing exposing the sticky side. Dont keep the shield too far from the phone and don't delay after peeling, dust is your enemy and there is dust in the air. When you place it down, after aligning the cut outs, you will see like magic, all the bubbles disappear. There are cutouts or notches for the earpiece, proximity sensor, camera and home button. Once in place you will notice that the surface is coated to dramatically reduce fingerprints and smearing. The glass is also very clear and doesnt distort anything. This shield doesnt follow the curve of the iPhone glass but that can just lead to failure anyway. For extra protection put a case on the phone that has room for the glass shield and it will stay put even better.  There will be much less tendency for the edge of the shield to catch on a pants pocket. Overall Im happy with this protective glass cover.

This product was provided at or nearly no cost for the purpose of evaluation and review.

The clips do a great job holding the phone snugly without messing with the side buttons (my Nexus 6 has the volume and power buttons all on the same side and some of these holders have their clips right where the buttons are).

Obviously the wireless charging is going to be slower than the fast charging direct cables. Sometimes if I have GPS and music going and the screen is on, it may not add to the charge, but just keeps it at a steady battery level. But that's really all I need, since I can plug it in at home if needed.

The pivot point works well, letting me adjust the angle and holding it right where I put it.
