One short and sweet one liner -> Nexus 5 is literally a big brother of iPhone 5s. Its as beautiful as black iPhone 5S and Kitkat OS is on par (actually better) with iOS. You can say its bigger iPhone (I mean it) because Android OS is more flexible, customizable and powerful and it is bigger than in size like its big brother. The bigger size definitely helps in games and all kind of media consumption.

This device performance is buttery smooth and the overall experience inspires utmost satisfaction. Given its size it feels so light and slim even compared to iPhone 5/5s.

It is not even best nexus device so far but best out yet among all.

And now I will explain it.
--------------------------
1. Design, look and build quality-> I differ here from most reviewers who says its plain or boring and nothing stands out of this. Its as good looking as black (space gray) iPhone 5S. Its all black like iPhone 5s. Though its made of plastic its feels sturdy, well built with precision only known to Apple. And for the people who tell iPhone made of aluminum, Nexus 5 sides appears no inferior to iPhone 5S black sides. The front glass is very well fused with the body with almost no gaps. Now what we are left with? Back? The back of Nexus 5 is though made of plastic it feels very good in the hand and due to its matte finish does not seem to slip off.

Now one step further...
iPhone 5S black (or space gray) seems to have identity crisis of being black or something else, Nexus 5 black is perfectly black and it has got radically different sides (not plain round rectangle which all other smartphones have). The sides are beautifully something else.
iPhone 5S beauty is revealing and Nexus 5 beauty being black is mysterious and never gets boring.

I love this black beauty and don't blame for my taste as they said "beauty lies in the eyes of beholders".

"Simplicity is Beauty and Beauty is simplicity, nothing more, nothing less." - Oscar Wilde. If any phone on the market lives up to the Oscar Wilde's quote its Nexus 5.

In short its unapologetically simple".

2. Processor/speed-> Buttery/silky smooth. Neck to neck with iPhone 5s and second only to Note 3 for all practical purposes.

3. Screen/display-> Awesome. Its better than retina any time as its full HD. The feeling of display being washed up goes away very soon and remember the so called best retina have the same problem as they share the same display technology.

4. Ecosystem-> Android eco system is as good as Apple's. In fact I find it better because of Android OS power you have kind of powerful applications which Apple fan boys can never have. Apple fan boys just give a try to 'tasker' (Warning: Only if you can handle Android's raw power.)

5. Powerful Soul-> "Fools are those who don't want their souls to be powerful." Its as good as iOS but better why? because its powerful and customizable. You can do the things with it when you need. Its no way comparable to inferior iOS. Apple fan boys! People should not be proud of a system which does not even let them change default for anything.

6. Call Quality -> Fantastic. I have never had so clear voice on call for very long.

7. Network Signal Quality -> Fantastic.

8. Volume/Speaker-> Inherently the speaker is very loud. Though in some application it might sound a little short of enough but its software related problem and should be fixed in future update. I have tested the volume in many application like play and in some apps are freaking load. While playing music through play I had to cut down on the volume in car its so powerful.

With headphones its fantastic. The voice quality is very superior and has no noise in it. Its as pure as it gets.

9. Camera-> I have seen all the comparisons of Nexus 5 with all leading phones (HTC one, Nokia Lumia, iPhone 5s, Samsung Galaxy S4) and its competing neck to neck in every department except its little slow to focus. But once it focus it takes very good images. HDR+ beats all other phones (I swear it). But again Google admitted it was software related issue and would be fixed soon through update. Personally I am pretty satisfied with the camera.

Its at least best nexus phone camera and comparable to others except in little slower to focus. The photos are very detailed with accurate colors.

Note: I have uploaded some photos for reference.

10. Battery-> No complaints. Nothing great or bad here. Its definitely better than many old phones (including galaxy nexus) and equal to many others.

It just falls short of only two smart phones right now which are LG G2 and Note 3. But it's battery is comparable to the best smartphone i.e. iPhone 5s. So if iPhone 5S can be the best with that kind of battery I don't understand how we could complain of Nexus 5. For casual usage you will charging it once a day. The noticeable thing is that in idle mode it does not eat battery at all and that's where it will average out better end of the day.

11. Reparability-> iFixit has given its 8 of 10 in this department and you should feel comfortable saving your money on costly repair by doing many things yourself and the whole assembly is modular.

Summary-> Even keeping its lower price aside, Its the one of best smart phone and should equal or better any best smart phone on the planet right now. And you add advantage of lower price...
summary: Its big brother of iPhone (5s) literally, best nexus phone and best smart phone period

reviewText:
Delivery was very quick. The product is actually great. I've used Invisible Shield and hated the orange peel effect and I've also used Body Guardz. Neither came close to the quality this screen protector provides. I'd definitely recommend to anyone else.

A couple of notes for people who may need assurance on installation...
Make sure to really wet your fingers and the front and back of the screen protector. I've also sprayed some solution on my screen. I laid the screen protector on the screen until it was gliding above the screen. Afterwards, I brushed out gently with the squeegee and cloth until air bubbles were gone. There were no air bubbles left actually. Once it was applied, (although they recommended not to turn on your device after installation, I did so anyhow) the screen looked pixelated. Although, I did this right before I slept so I woke up the next morning and the pixelation faded away maybe about 3/4. Within the next day, The screen was almost crystal clear. A week later my screen is crystal! I will post pictures.

One take away though is that I do feel the sensitivity of the screen is less responsive. Not so much, but enough to notice a tad difference.

-------Edit 8/18

Okay so sensitivity issue is completely gone. It's as good as bare screen. The only thing that's bugging me right now is these two dents on the screen that won't heal...creating air bubbles or artifacting underneath. In that area its terrible response. I know I can take it off, clean it, and reapply but that's too much hassle and its tolerable. Just to note, after washing your hands, using the screen is near unbearable (But that goes to about any screen protector) in that your fingers don't slide almost at all and you kind of require some finger sweat or oil to make it smooth again. Overall, this product is great. Recommended it to many friends and bought them and they seem to be satisfied.

-------Edit 10/16

The screen protector is starting to peel off and scratches are developing. It's quite unsightly. I still recommend it for the clarity. I'd like to request a new one though.
summary: Better than Invisible Shield and Body Guardz

reviewText:
This tempered glass screen protector looks great on my Samsung Galaxy Note 5 and I have piece of mind knowing that it is safe and secure. One thing I really like about this screen protector and I've used many is how little fingerprints and smudges shows up on it. The ones that do are much less smudgy than others that I've used and they are very easily wiped away. This protector cleans so easy that I can't believe the difference it is from my last screen protector, also glass. It's always looking crystal clear and there is no glare or rainbow effect from this tempered glass which is a great plus.

The tempered glass is a little bit thinner than others but you still get that protection you want from scratches and marks on your devices original screen. This is maximum hardness so not to worry needing it to be so thick and it feels a little nicer to the touch. There is also another point I would like to mention and that is that this tempered glass is very smooth. I use the S pen a lot and it is very nice to write something and I would say even nicer that writing on the bare screen and the touch sensitivity is equal to the screen itself. My scrolling is the smoothest I've felt both with S pen and just my finger and this glass protector is my choice now that I've tried it for myself.

I have used many protectors and most of the big named brands and in my opinion this protector is right at the top of my list. I would highly recommend you to give it a try for yourself it's worth it and the price is very reasonable. Nice tempered glass screen protector I'm very impressed by it. I just recently heard about Google Cardboard VR and was curious to try it out for myself.  Owl's version of the Cardboard VR was a great way to try out the experience.  Assembly was really easy.  Just flip the cardboard flaps out and connect everything together where you see the velcro tabs.  I have a larger phone (LG Optimus Pro G) and while my phone did not fit with the case on, it did fit perfectly without the case.  There was an elastic band that is meant to hold this to your head for hands free VR.  Just secure the velcro tabs roughly eye level and you are good to go.  Also, the button for interacting with the screen worked perfectly with my phone.

After using the unit several times, there are a couple areas that I feel could be improved.
1)  The nose piece is pretty rough and can begin to hurt after a few minutes.  A simple silicone nose piece could resolve that discomfort.
2)  While its hard to design a one size fits all device for phones and cases, I would have liked to see a little more room where you insert your phone.  Any dead space could be filled in with foam spacers for a customized fit for more phones and allowing some use with slim cases.

The Google Cardboard apps requests that you scan a bar code on the viewer to get started.  It recognized this Owl viewer right away and the experience worked great.  I recommend that you have a higher end phone as there was a little lag when I used it which made me dizzy since you are so close to the action.  Thats no fault of the Owl viewer, but just a tip for anyone new to Google Cardboard.  You can even download the app and try it before ordering to see if your phone can handle it.  You will just see your screen in a "fisheye split view" but can see if it lags.

Overall this is a great way to test out the Google VR experience.  I received this kit gratis for my honest review.
summary: Great way to test out the Google VR experience

As you can tell from the pictures this is a nicely made case with genuine leather and hand stitching and a magnetic leather flap. The flap has interior pockets that can hold 2 credit cards/IDs and some cash. The chocolate color is nice and the case looks nice - not like some cheap leather ones that look very plasticky. The inside hard case is black and does hold the iPhone without covering up the edges like a slimfit case that I really like.

I thought it was a perfect case for the times I did not want to take the whole purse, like on a walk, for outdoor activities or to a club at night. However, I very soon realized that after you put the phone in it, it's hard to talk on it unless you flip out the top flap and hold it to the back of the phone. That makes it awkward, plus if you have cash or IDs in it you would not like to flip out the whole thing and have it fall out. Repeated folding back of the top flap is also creasing the leather and it will look unattractive, so I'd rather not do that. So if I don't flip the top flap back the phone is fine for browsing or texting but it's really awkward to make calls on it unless I use a bluetooth or a headphone. I am not sure I want to do that.

One other limiting factor for me is that since I saw this case as a special occasion case for outdoors or for clubs I have to pop out my iPhone from it's regular case and put it in this case. This case holds the iPhone really tight, which is great but doesn't really make it easy to switch it back and forth. So despite the good looks the design does not work for my usage and it will not be getting much use.

I received a free sample for review like the 3 other reviewers. However, I find the current price a little too high and even if this was a useful case for me I would look for a slightly lower priced alternative due to the high price.
summary: Very well made case and great protection, but not so useful for every day use.

reviewText: Great Screen Protector...Very easy to apply...
Not at all the right part for my fire hd 8.9 2nd gen.

First off, all the cutouts on this (my clear version) are perfect, including the bottom mic cutout.  Like others have said, this should offer moderate drop protection at a good price.  The 'lip' that wraps around does give you maybe 3 or 4 millimeters of buffer if you drop your device face down, for a softer case like this I wouldn't go it on purpose because of the small lip-slip-off risk, but it should help fairly well for face down.

Also, there is a rise/bump surrounding the camera lens, very happy to see this, as you know sitting this device down all the time, it's basically resting on the surround of the camera - this is exactly what I got this cover for.

The fit is very good, but not excellent, I have a very small maybe 1mm of flop on the bottom, but not enough to not recommend this product.

The power and volume 'buttons' will take some getting used to, obviously putting 'rubber' over a button reduces responsiveness, but I'm sure after a couple days I'll be used to it.

Clear color is perfect, but it's only day 1, really hopeful this does not yellow, at least for a few months.

Overall for the price, very please with this cover.

reviewText: This case offers good protection and doesn't feel overly bulky. I am not disappointed with this purchase!

Wow!  I think one word is really enough for a review of this case.

I tend to favor less rather than more when it comes to cases in order to not feel like I'm carrying a brick in my pocket.  Most of the armor cases are simply out of the question due to their weight.  That still typically left me with plenty of choices but given the curved edges of the S6 Edge, I thought it might be hard to find a case to my satisfaction.  Prior to this, I got the Enther Clear case and Spigen Slim case.  With Enther, I found the buttons hard to press and the protection not nearly enough to absorb any sort of a drop considering how thin it is around the edges.  With the Spigen, I had a case with the same material before few years ago and I know the plastic may not substain a drop.  I also looked at the Spigen Neo Hybrid but decided against it due to it only available in dark colors.  I got a white phone and I wanted some bright colors!!

After looking around, I finally landed on this Caseology Wavelength case for the Edge.  All around, it is a very solid case that is well made beyond the $16 that I spent on it.  The bumpers on all four sides are just thick enough that I feel comfortable that they will protect the phone.  It feels like Caseology properly tested the case and got the right feel to it without sacrificing the look.  Especially with the rubber back, it feels grippy and is good looking at the same time.  The buttons have a solid feel and I definitely didn't feel like I have to make too much effort pushing them unlike the Enther case.  At the same time, I don't accidentally press the buttons by accidents either because the pressure really feel just right.  Also, the case looked and felt like it totally wrapped around the phone that the phone won't pop out on a drop and it is not difficult to remove just in case you want to change it out.

The only minor regret is with the cutout for the camera and flash.  It is one big cutout like majority of other cases, though I understand it does make things easier for them to have it that way, it seems that having specific cutout for both the camera and the flash separately would make it look even better.

Pro:
It feels nice in hand
It is well constructed
It looks like it'll protect the phone well while not taking away from the look
It is thin and grippy
Buttons feel just right
Color is vibrant and design hit the right notes in the right area

Minor Con:
Single cutout for both camera and flash
summary: Best case for the S6 edge hands down

That being said, the integrity of it's protection is another story.  This thing is still holding up pretty well from my wife throwing it in her purse (keys and all).  For amount of money (~$15) you spend on this case, it's almost worth the annual investment to replace it.

I would recommend this case for the protection, but would not recommend it if you would have issues of a dulling clear case.

I have had IMP52D for the last few days and I have to say- it's one of the best chargers I have used. The biggest thing I noticed right off the bat was how small it was. Much smaller then I was expecting. The size makes it easy to carry around in pocket, briefcase or just about anything. The size also makes it really nice to be able to have it charging a device and leave them connected in pocket without a bunch of bulk.

Having the laser pointer and flash light built in is really nice. It makes the IMP52D the perfect extra device to carry around in briefcase since it can also be used in a meeting for a pointer (plus it looks nice so it won't be out of place at a business meeting or lunch). It took me a litte bit to figure out how to use the single button to true on/off the laser, flashlight and charger. But once I got it figured out, it was easy to use. (I like to see if I can figure out devices without having to read manual. To me, if it is designed right, I shouldn't need the manual- and I didn't for the IMP52D)

The only issue I have is if I used a regular usb cable, it would only charge some of my devices at usb speeds. Since there is the include cables, shorting adaptor and case though, I don't see that being a big issue since the bag makes it easy to keep the "right" cable with the charger.

The IMP52D is definitely going to be the go to charger in my everyday bag.

Likes:
1) Size - easily pocketable
2) Appearance- doesn't look out of place at a business function
3) built in laser pointer and light
4) Comes with the needed "shorted" cables and bag to carry

Dislike:
1) Required "special" cables to charge devices at full AC speeds.

This case feels like it offers great protection at an affordable cost.

One of the things I really like about these Buddibox cases is the shock-absorbing design on the corners.  Usually when a phone is dropped on the corner all of the impact goes straight into the screen, usually shattering it.  This case is designed in a way that takes that shock and distributes it into the outer edges of the case instead, protecting your screen.  I haven't really seen this design in any other cases and I think it's really smart.

This case came with a screen protector, which I think it nice.  It's the typical thin plastic kind, but if you don't have one yet it could save your screen.

This case has two parts- the inner Polycarbonate flexible layer and an outer thick rigid plastic layer for extra protection.  This outer layer has a slot where you can stand it up using a credit card (or a gift card! Don't use a credit card in public or you're setting yourself up for identity theft.)  This feature is nice if you want to watch a video.  The two layers will come apart if you want to remove the outer layer for any reason.

This case wraps around in front of the screen, protecting it from a face down drop, but does not have front coverage (except for the free screen protector)

The only thing I dislike about this case is that the buttons are hard to push.  I press the side buttons on my phone a lot and I've noticed it takes significantly more effort with this case.  Maybe it's just me being lazy, but I like button pressing to be easy.  On the plus side, this probably means the buttons are well protected.  All other ports are open and easy to access, but don't have any protection, so it's a trade off.

Overall, This is a pretty nice case for the cost.  I received this item at no charge in return for my honest review, which I have provided here.  All opinions are my own and not effected by the cost of the item.

But back to the charger. The charge has a nice gloss finish that make the charge nice and shine and has 2x 2.4 Amp Smart USB ports. So all you devices will charge faster and be safe from over charge or over heating issues.  This charger works so great I actually replaced my original Apple one. The charger will get hot if you are charging 2 devices at the same time.

Now to the cable they include. The cable is not a MFI Certified Lighting Cable, but the cable has a slight issue when using it to charge the iPad. For some reason when using this cable to charge your iPad it will take forever for it to be completely charge. It takes a good 6 hours to charge from 10% to 100% Vs only 3 hours with most other cables. Also when testing the cable I notice that when it charges an iPhone It will pop up the message that states This Accessory may not be supported when the Phone is done charging. But the cable look awesome because of the cable is fiber optic laced which makes the cable stand out.

So I would defiantly recommend the charger to people but not the cable that is included because it seems like there is something wrong with the cable that is included. So IXCC might want to take a look at it and see why it won't work correctly but the charger itself is still worth buying even if the cable doesn't work right.

reviewText:
I have been an iPhone 3G user for over a year and I love the iPhone. However I hate iTunes so I wanted to look into an Android phone.
The Samsung Infuse has a beautiful screen, it's slim and light, and navigation seemed easy enough. I like the Android interface, customizations, widgets, and the beautiful live wallpaper. Apps opened very quickly and ran well.
The sound quality on my Samsung Infuse was not as clear and good as my iPhone 3G. I had a few people complain that they had difficulty hearing me. One of those times I was on a Bluetooth headset, and I never had a single complaint about sound quality with my headset on my iPhone, but on this phone my husband couldn't hear me well with the bluetooth headset enabled.
The signal strength was not as good as my iPhone 3G. I lost my signal in areas where I was able to make calls from my iPhone. I was disappointed because I do live in a rural area with lots of weak signal areas, and I need a phone that works in those areas!  The iPhone always did well for me, even in weak signal areas.
Another problem for me was the phone was a little too wide for my hands. With the iphone, I had it in a case and the case fit well against the palm of my hand. This phone, being so thin and flat, I could only grip it by the beveled edge. My palm had no contact with the phone. It slipped out of my hand so many times! The phone feels so fragile because it's thin. That said, it fit really well in my pocket (without a case). I was afraid of breaking it all the time though.
I am left-handed, and that's never really been a problem before in using a phone, however with the Samsung Infuse, maybe because the screen is so wide, I found it was really awkward to hold and control with my left hand. The volume rocker on the left and the power button on the right are positioned in such a way I was getting them constantly and annoyingly confused.
Another issue that may just affect left-handers, according to what I read on the internet (may not be true, I can't confirm) when you answer the phone with your right hand, something inside the phone (accelerometer maybe?) senses the movement and understands you are answering the phone, and it locks the touch screen so you don't accidentally touch the "end call" button. It didn't screen-lock when I answered so I ended up accidentally hanging up on people.
The phone has a front-facing camera but as of this writing, it doesn't support Skype video chat.
The screen is beautiful, however there is no Netflix app like there is for the iPhone, and no Hulu plus app, although there are some other android phones that can get Hulu plus.
The music player wasn't very easy to use or very handy, the battery life was poor for me - it could not hold a charge through a full day, on my unit, the headphone jack didn't work. All of these things combined to make it the wrong choice of phone for me.
summary: Too New, Not Intuitive Enough For Me

Works. Not much else to say about something like this. I got the device because I found myself with a lot of stuff to charge beside me at night.

I use this charger with non-data enabled USB cables. In fact, it's the only reason I got this vs. a Qualcomm Quick Charge (QC) 2.0 or 3.0 bank. You're not supposed to use non-data enabled USB cables with those devices (I don't know the reason). So to be safe, I got this for all of my non-QC enabled devices so I don't have to use the ports on my other bank that I got that IS QC enabled on all ports.

As I mentioned, it charges all of my devices well. The block itself is rather compact and feels very solid. I got one in each color, black and white. There's a little light to indicate that the device is plugged in. You also get a nice long power cable.

+4 stars because it's clean, good power. Measured, I do get up to ~2.3A per port when using all ports and my non-data enabled usb cables. I get just a bit less than that with data enabled usb cables.

-1 star because I may actually have to move it out of my bedroom due to noise. The device makes a hissy/whiney noise and even though I like sound while sleeping (music, TV, etc), whenever the room becomes quiet the noise this makes stands out big time. Suffice it to say, it's very annoying if you're sitting there reading your tablet or phone in a quiet room. My wife also hears it and she sleeps on the opposite side. It doesn't wake us up, it's not loud noise, it's just consistent noise. If it annoys me, it will annoy anyone imho, especially those requiring a quiet bedroom.

In the end, it's not a deal breaker for me. I'll likely move it to the living room or some other area so I can quickly pop a device or 6 to charge. I have my eye on another device, which I also own that is completely quiet. I may just spring to get another one, it's a few dollars more than this but worth it.
summary: Works, but has a noise problem.

Candy Shell cases by Speck are neat.  They have an inner silicone layer and a hard plastic outer shell, a lot like an OtterBox Commuter case.  But unlike the OtterBox, the Speck is one piece.  You won't spend time massaging silicone around to get a good fit.  The solid of-a-piece construction and the fairly large raised edge around the perimeter of the glass screen gives you a lot of confidence that your phone will survive if you drop it on the sidewalk.

The Candy Shell case fits the iPhone 5S just fine.  The Lightning port opening is large enough to fit third party cables, including the Amazon Basic Lightning cable.

Candy Shell cases are very hansom in my opinion.  The glossy black plastic married to the dark gray silicone makes a good looking combination.  But the hansom glossy plastic shell is also the worst feature of this case.

The glossy surface scratches ridiculously easily.  I installed my phone and laid it on its back on my wood desk.  That's all it took to put scuffs and scratches all over the back of the case.  The glossy plastic also attracts dust.  A lot of it.  You'll be amazed how much lint is in your pocket.  This is especially bad news because the dusty crud tends to build up around the camera opening.

What the Speck Candy Shell case does well it does really well.  Just don't expect it to keep its looks for more than a day.  Four stars.

I received a discount code voucher in order to purchase this Galaxy S7 wallet case for review, giving my honest opinion. I LOVE this case. I love things that are multi use and this case fits the bill. I had bought a similar case previous to this, but this one is so much better. The case itself is a black, smooth leathery material. There is a chrome accent strip on the outside, and I LOVE chrome of any kind. The threading on the inside is red, which is not only cool, but in a rush you can tell which side you are on by the color. The outside thread is black. The inside pockets are a little cheap. I fear they won't last too long with multiple uses. The pockets are cut in a way that makes it easy to put in and take a card out, but they are not reinforced so they are brittle. Behind the card holders is a large hidden pocket, more storage is always a plus. Now the best part, the phone case that attaches to the phone itself, is a separate piece!! So this piece is has the same smooth black leather like material covering the back, which makes it match the folding case. The inside where the phone goes in, is a smooth matte plastic which prevents the phone from scratching. That piece stays on the phone and attaches to the folding case by way of magnet. The magnet is very strong, the phone attaches easily with minimal effort, and it goes on straight, automatically. Super cool. Previous phone cases like this did not have this magnet feature. It was difficult to take pictures or put the phone to your ear when talking on the phone. But now you can remove the phone for these purposes. The magnetic snap closes easily on the folding case, keeping everything in a nice neat package.
Good.

summary: Awesome product for a low price

reviewText:
I wanted a simple case that had some "grip" to it, and this fit the bill.

The case goes on and off easily.  It has just enough rubber texture to it to make it not slide off your lap, the table, etc., but not so much grip that it collects lint or won't slide into your pocket or purse.

The ports on the phone are all easily accessed -- and I like that this case turns the volume buttons and the off button 3-dimensional (versus just having a cutout where you have to reach inside to access them, like some similar cases).  The mute button is just accessed through a cutout in the case (but that would pretty much have to be accessed in that manner).

The best feature is that the cutout over the rear camera/flash is large, so the flash won't bounce off the colored case and ruin your picture.  I bought another brand (Mercury) in a similar style case first, but that cutout over the camera and flash was smaller -- the case was green, and all flash pictures were colored green and blurred every time.  There are NO noticeable problems like that with this case, I am happy to report.

Nice job on this one -- finally, a decent iPhone case without any obvious flaws.  They're harder to come by than it might seem!
summary: Just about perfect; flash photos work great!

I've tried a few different variants of these 3D VR Goggles and found this one to be one of the best - quality wise.  It's comfortable on your face, easily adjustable, and the phone stays in there very tightly.

Few people have complained about the "nose bridge",but I found it to be very comfortable - no problems wearing it for a long period of time.

I have had three problems (maybe user error):

1) I have an iPhone 6S Plus that's in a case.  I don't think the phone will fit into the goggles within the case.  For me to use the goggles, I have to take the phone out of the case.

2) The way that the phone goes into the goggles seems strange.  Maybe I'm missing something ,but there doesn't seem to be a good way to pry the two "holders" apart to put the phone in.  Again, once it's in there, it's in tight.  But, it seems like there should be a way to pull the holders apart and I couldn't seem to do it.

3) Shouldn't these goggles have a "magnet" or something to initiate an action/  I can't find it.

I'm going to send this message to the seller and see if they can help me - because this might just be me.
summary: Once you get your phone in there, these are great quality goggles.

reviewText:
Awesome, in true Arkon fashion. I've gotten to the point where Arkon is my preferred brand for automotive device mounts. I bought this for use in my classic 1979 Pontiac Trans Am, which is a totally kick ass car, right? Well, a kick ass car like that deserves nothing more than an equally kick ass mobile device mount. Arkon delivers, yet again. Check out the pictures, which I took right before posting this review. I love this thing (the device mount, not the car. Well, I obviously love the car too, it took nearly 2 years of my life to build it so I love it more than the Arkon mount for sure and probably even more than several people in my family, but as it relates to this review I really do love how this mobile device mount functions and looks in my car).

I also really dig the interchangeability of the parts and the high-quality plastic used too. Not that I really interchange them all that much, actually never, but it's really nice knowing that I can if I ever want to. Not that I will. Either way, I will definitely buy again and recommend to friends and family (the family not noted above as being loved less than my kick ass car).

Oh, by the way, there's nothing but brutal honesty posted in this review. I bought this Arkon mount with my own semi-hard-to-barely-earned money and I am not one of those review for hire trolls that suck up review space and reader time.

The cardboard standard requires a magnet button; this does not have one, making it inoperable with many apps, including the initial Cardboard app.

For the same amount of money or less, you can buy VR goggles that don't have this debilitating omission.

The fabrication cost of this product was around $3 in China or some other low-cost country. Adding the magnet would have cost about $0.25 more. They are selling this incomplete product for approximately 10x the manufacturing cost.

reviewText:
EDITED TO UPDATE REVIEW: 6/16/2015: The longer I've had this case and compare it to others, the better I like it. If I could add another star to my review I would. In fact, I like it so much I'm ordering another one, in a different color, just because. Best. Case. Ever.

I am pleasantly surprised by the Q Case for my iPhone 6+. The build quality is excellent. It's unbelievably thin, considering it can easily hold three of my credit cards and a couple of folded $20 bills. Also, it's really good looking. I bought the gold colored case. Very stylish. Feels great in the hand. Not too slippery, but also won't stick in your pocket so you have to fumble for it.

The front of the case wraps over the front of the phone, giving the screen protection so that you can lay the phone down on its face. The buttons work perfectly over top of the iPhone's buttons. Really easy to feel them, but also not obtrusive. Someone really put a lot of thought into this case.

I had thought that I'd only be using this case for travel, but the truth is I've never taken it off the phone because I like that much more than my other cases (Apple silicone and leather cases).

It will also allow for the use of any screen protector, including the relatively thick Zagg Glass Protectors.

Absolutely recommend this case, especially because it won't break your bank either.
summary: Best Case I've Found For My iPhone 6+

I received my LG G5 Anti-Glare Screen Protector today from IQ Shield. First of all the shipping was extremely fast and I received my product earlier than expected. After opening and examining the screen protector, I am extremely impressed with the quality of the product, the accessories included, and the instructions provided.

This screen protector is an excellent choice for people who are looking for better protection for their phone's screen, while at the same time reducing glare. The nice thing about this product is that it offers a matte appearance (think of a glossy picture versus a matte one).

One really nice feature is the feel of this screen protector. It has a finish that is very comfortable to touch and does not take away from the functionality of the phone.

After examining the product, I can tell right away how thick the protector is which is perfect for someone wanting a durable finish for their screen. This is a premium product and it shows through the packaging, quality of the screen protector itself, and warranty. I did receive this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review. I always provide my unbiased opinion because I know how many people rely on quality reviews when making purchases from Amazon.
summary: A great choice for the LG G5!

I purchased a Samsung Note 8.0 and needed a screen protector. After doing a thorough search, i decided to try the Tech Armor protector. The package comes with TWO protectors in case you mess one up and have to do it again. I only had to apply the screen protector once and it went on flawless. A few pointers: clean your screen to the best it can be before applying the protector. Try to use it in a closed room with little airflow or dust eventually settles and you get those bubbles that never come out.

Pros: One try and comes with two protectors
Cons: There is an extra slot in the top of the protector near the Samsung logo that is not necessary for the note 8.0
summary: Best screen protector for the Note 8.0

Just received this dock and I really like it. Unlike some reviews I have read this dock appears to be an original Twelve South Dock. All parts including the back post align perfectly. I even received the Twelve South appliqu another reviewer said was missing from their box. This was an Amazon-Twelve South purchase, not from a third party vendor.

As other reviewers have stated you must use the smaller 1 millimeter Apple cable. My iPhone 6 plus was shipped with the 2 millimeter cable so I used the cable I was using for my iPod Touch. The unit assembles pretty easily. I tested the dock plugs with my case on my phone before inserting into the post. I use the Speigen Tough Armor Case and the number 2 plug fits perfectly. The case is stable enough. I do use my second hand to hold the base when removing the phone. I have had to do that with other docks too. Under normal circumstances the phone is secure on the dock. Small children with prying fingers could topple it.

I would like to mention to Twelve South that if they used a magnetized Allen wrench it would make inserting those four screws much easier. I mean this is a premium dock so it would be nice to have a premium experience assembling it. I also had to work with it to keep the wire cover snap out piece on the underside bottom of the base from coming loose even though the cable was firmly seated in the grooves. I removed the little cellophane type "pull" piece and then is snapped and stayed in place.

Over all I am very pleased with the premium look and the functionality of this dock. My back support works perfectly and fully supports the back of the phone. And the absolute best thing I like about this dock is it should work with future iPhones. The design is ingenious. The one thing I hate is spending a lot of money for an iPhone accessory only to have it rendered useless when Apple redesigns their phone. This dock is so adjustable that I believe that problem will be eliminated with future phones unless Apple has a very radical design change such as curving the phones.  And the fact that this dock will work with a large variety of cases out there is the biggest plus of all.

I decided to take a picture of the dock. Some previous reviews have stated that the back post is cut incorrectly rendering the back support useless. They obviously did not receive an actual "Twelve South" dock. As you can see my back support aligns perfectly. Again, I ordered this through Amazon Prime - Twelve South, not a third party vendor. I feel you are pretty safe by ordering the dock this way. And if something is wrong it is much easier returning to Amazon vs. a vendor.
summary: Just received this dock and I really like it. Unlike some reviews I have read this ...

In my opinion, there's nothing prettier than a fun gadget in rose gold. I'm so glad more companies are making rose gold items. This set comes with the selfie stick itself, a micro USB charging cable, a wrist strap, phone safety guard, drawstring bag and a set of instructions.
This selfie stick does NOT come with a wall adapter for it.

The selfie stick instruction sheet is pretty dismal so if you are unfamiliar with how to work it you will definitely need to see the instructions on the product page. The selfie stick is Bluetooth enabled, so you do not have to plug your phone into it for it to function. The main features that set it apart from a basic unit are the photo light and mirror; both of which can be used to ensure that you look your best in your photos. In order to power the light, you just need to plug in the cord on the side of the stick to the port next to the light. The light has three brightness settings and can be rotated to suit your preferences. The handle has an ergonomic design and grooves for your fingers which makes it easy to maneuver as needed. The fit is a bit snug with my iPhone 6 but still manageable.

Pros:
 Luxury Selfie Stick
 Bluetooth Shutter
 Rear Mirror
 LED Light
 Works with Most Smart Phones
 Beautiful Design and Colors
 Front & Rear Selfie Capabilities
 Long Battery Life

This particular selfie stick extends to approximately 2 feet. I received this at no cost for my evaluation and honest review.
summary: Beautiful rose gold, 2' extending selfie stick.

reviewText:
The Starter Kit is composed of one Proximo fob with a button and one Proximo tag without a button.

I followed the instructions included, downloaded the iPhone app, and everything was connected via Bluetooth flawlessly. However, the product really isn't effective.

It was advertised that the fob/tag or the iPhone would sound an alarm set and record the location via GPS if the two ever lost connection. In praticality, this application was severely flawed. The problem became that the two would lose connection less than a foot from each other and the alarm would never activate.

There was only one time the fob was useful. It was when I had my keys and fob but couldn't find my phone (it was under a blanket) and I pushed the button for the alarm. However, this could have been accomplished by simply calling my phone (if I had another phone, which some people might not--hence, why there was some value).

This product has a great idea and would fulfill a large need...but it simply doesn't work as well as intended. It's a case of the spirit is willing but the flesh is weak at this point--save your money and wait for the technology to improve.

reviewText: Love it

Having used several Speck and other protective cases for our iPhone 6s, I decided to place an order for the Speck Mighty Shell with Faceplate Case, especially after reading the  manufacturers description, namely It's all the protection you've been looking for - and in a super slim design. Speck's Mighty Shell + FACEPLATE outperforms the military drop test standard by 2X.
Following the pictorial application instruction, I removed the old Speck CandyShell Grip Case and Screen Protector from one of our iPhone 6,  and proceeded to install the Mighty Shell Case, and FacePlate.  Inserting the iPhone 6 into the MS Case was a snap, and after peeling the protective film off the FacePlate as shown, applied it to the iPhone 6.  A couple small bubbles were easily pressed out with the furnished microfiber cloth.  The FacePlate removal instructions are also included in the event of misalignment and/or dust bubbles - a sticking tool for removing dust is also in the package.  Over all the installation went as advertised.  This is a neat case, more protection the Speck CandyShell Grip, and, the True Tap Screen Protector is in fact more responsive IMHO than generic screen protectors we used on the iPhone 6s.  The Mighty Shell Case weighs the same as the CandyShellGrip - 1.3 ounces.
Overall, the Mighty Shell with/FacePlate is a significant improvement over the older model case, in addition to providing 2X shatter proof, scratch resistant, and anti-fingerprint  protection. Recommended.

  Information provided by Speck:

  2x military-grade protection
  Meets double the requirements for MIL-STD-810G military-grade drop tested protection standards.
  3 layers harnessed into only 0.18" for surprising protection in a slim profile.
  Perimeter bumper provides superior control and comfort for quick calls and fast fingers.
  Ultra hard layer guards against scratches and finger prints
  Rigid layer disperses energy from impact
  Ultra soft layer absorbs shockSemi-rigid layer spreads impact
  Adhesive layer bonds screen withTrueTaptechnology

It just sits in there, didn't bother to use the adhesive. I don't notice it using the phone, but wow, does the magnet ever grab on. No worries whatsoever about the phone slipping or falling off this mount.

And I should say something about the suction cup too. Garmin, if you're listening, this is what you should be using. My Garmin GPS mound falls off the windshield regularly, rarely stays on more than a few days. This thing has been in place for weeks! Just a terrific, terrific mount.

***Update***
Switch from an iPhone 5 to an LG G3 and bought the air vent version as well. I slipped the round metal disc inside the G3 Circle Case, and even though the G3 and case are rounded at the back, it fits inside neatly. And the magnet holds pretty well through the Circle Case, but not if you fold the cover all the way back. Meaning the magnet work through 1 layer of case, but not 2.
summary: Holy Moses is that magnet strong!!

Lets be honest, not very many people use the CD slot in their cars anymore. These days, we have the radio, bluetooth, and aux plugs to listen to our favorite songs. This is where Koomus comes in. Koomus is a company who makes many different mounts for smartphones and tablets. They have an awesome little mount called the Pro CD Slot Car Mount. This mount allows you to mount your phone, or small tablet in the CD slot of your car. The first thing I noticed when I took the mount out of the packaging was its weight. Its super lightweight. The body is plastic, the grips are rubber, and the extendable clamp is made of metal. The metal clamp is what grips your phone and holds it securely in place. I was actually a bit surprised with how good of quality the clamp is. It can accommodate any phone or tablet as long as it is within 3.4 inches wide. I clamped in my iPhone 6s Plus with a case, and it had no problem holding it up. To insert the mount, you must push the top button, and insert it into the CD slot of your car. The mount itself has rubber on both sides which is how it secures itself in the CD slot. Surprisingly, it gets a very sturdy grip. I tested this mount on 3 different cars, and it fit in every one. There was one car that it had a very tight fit, and required a little extra force to fully insert. An awesome feature of this mount is its 360 degree rotating capabilities. You can rotate your phone at any angle thats comfortable for you or your passenger. One thing I wish this mount had was a higher quality ball. The ball is the part that the mount rotates around. The plastic ball works fine, but I think the rotation could be even smoother if a higher quality material was used such as metal. I think the Koomus Pro CD Slot is a great car accessory to have. Its super convenient considering not too many people use their CD slots anymore. And if you happened to need access to your CD slot, the big button on the top makes it easy to remove. Overall, the construction of this mount gets an 8/10. The plastic body is sturdy and does what was intended, but I would have loved to see more metal on a device like this. Honestly, for $25.00, its not going to get much better than this. In conclusion, If you need a sturdy mount that will hold your device at a comfortable angle and won't fall down, this is the one.

reviewText: Excellent Product, Pretty amazing cover.

I use this very well made Anker 5 port power supply strip that I use for work. I drive a lot and have had no problems supplying power to an LG tablet, Galaxy S4, a hot spot and sometimes an additional phone. I've found Anker to be a great brand. Most companies produce high end to low end products with pricing to match. I would consider this to be one of their mid-range items but I feel they strive to produce high a quality product.

The cover is strong and very easy to grip.  I have dropped my phone 2 Times from my car to the concrete and there has been only scratches on the corner of the case.  It does what it is supposed to do.  At first I had a hard time pinching the cover together over the silicone part,  but after doing it about 6 Times,  it now stays together. The only fault I find with the cover: it is a little difficult to hit the back buttons.  The case is a little bulky there so I must use the side of my finger to use any of the peripheral features.  That is the only downfall I have experienced.  All in all,  I do recommend this case.  It is strong and works.
Reliable, durable micro USB cables, can never go wrong with Anker. If there are issues with the cords, customer service always has your back and usually will help with replacements, repairs, etc.
summary: Reliable, durable micro USB cables, can never go ...

I've been looking forward to a larger and non-pentile display for my WP7.5 compared to all the large Android devices out there. Coming from a Samsung Focus which I was quite happy with, it was nice that the cable and chargers are compatible. I was bummed that there wasn't a microSD expansion slot but managed to make it work with the zune wireless sync features. Also, it was unclear from the terrible AT&T and Samsung spec pages but there is indeed the FM radio feature (as part of the zune app).

I'm really amazed how thin the Focus S is and didn't initially plan to get a case but decided to afterwards since there is very little purchase for your fingers to wrap around. The extra screen real estate is great for news apps although I was a bit surprised that the tint turns a bit blue-ish when viewing angle turns extreme. Not a day to day issue at all. Also, it's nice that the camera is centered rather than at one of the edges as it's easier to get used to the angle.

The original Focus having the micro-USB was nice as it was easier to keep charged and using the device unlike the Focus S which is at the bottom (also like the iPhones).

The one buggy feature is that the ambient light sensor doesn't seem to control the display brightness very well - had to turn the feature off.

FInally, the snap on case on the back is interesting as it doesn't cover the entire back of the device. Not many reasons to do a soft reset anyway with the stability of Mango.

Honestly, when I ordered this I was skeptical on how this magnet mount would work.  After using it for a few days I don't think I'll ever want to go back to another mount.  The ease of just sitting in my car and placing the phone with case on to the magnet mount takes no effort.  The magnet holds the phone very snug, but can be easily slid off the magnet with one hand when you need to take the phone down.  I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a slim case that has a mount that is very well integrated.

reviewText:
Have now been using this phone long enough to say that it is an amazing buy. High-end specs for a moderate price. Appears that most of the initial "issues" people had with this phone had rapidly gotten fixes several months ago. I usually buy high-end Samsung phones a generation behind so I had a Samsung Galaxy Note 4 that I was still very satisfied with except that it had never ever had a decent fingerprint scanner.  I was caught between this phone and the OnePlus 3T (had been following OnePlus for several years).

Finally went with this phone for the higher screen specs, the Qualcomm Quick Charge 3 capabilities (I already had some Quick Charge 3 chargers), 128 micro sd card support, superior speakers, and it was available immediately on sale for 350 whereas the OnePlus 3T with the larger 128mg capacity wasn't available and it didn't seem it would available anytime soon and would be 480. 350 vs 440-480? Hmmm

ZTE now says the upgrade to Nougat is a matter of weeks. And oh yeah... the fingerprint scanner is awesome. I have a Spigen case on it that makes using the fingerprint scanner virtually 100% accurate (see pic). Unlocking the phone and unlocking various apps is a breeze! Love this phone.
summary: High-end specs for a moderate price. Winning!

reviewText: As advertised

ABOUT THIS REVIEW
I have acquired this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my fair and honest review. I take this very seriously, as I like many of you rely on these reviews when making purchases. Nothing has been asked of me other than to give an honest review of the product, and as you can see from my review history it has no effect on my opinion. As others have pointed out I would recommend that you don't just look at the ratings on these reviews, focus on the reasoning behind the ratings as that will give you much more insight into the product. The reviewer may be looking at the product for an entirely different use or from an entirely different perspective than you are. If this review has helped you to make a decision please hit the Yes button below. Thanks!

AMAZON AND MY RATING SYSTEM
My thoughts and criteria for products I review: (Amazons Rating Criteria in Parentheses)
1 star (I hate it!): Feel it's a waste of money. Will never use it again. Would never recommend. Not safe to use. Either throw away or return it.
2 stars (I don't like it): Don't like it and wouldn't use it again, but may still have at least 1 positive thing about it.
3 stars (Its ok): Product has both positives and negatives, and I may or may not continue using it. Someone else may like it more and is potentially still worth purchasing.
4 stars (I like it): Item as described in functionality purpose and quality. May have 1 or 2 things I don't care for or would change, but not big issues. Would recommend if asked, but wouldn't say I love it.
5 stars (I love it!): Practically perfect. Nothing lacking in functionality or quality. I Love it and would not only recommend, but would purchase for others and continue to purchase for myself.

MY THOUGHTS ABOUT THIS PRODUCT:
  This case is pretty functional, I carry 2 wallets one for my cards (credit/Health Ins/discount cards) the other for ID (license/work ID/ECT). I have been looking for a way to slim down to the necessities on off days or just hanging out. This is perfect! I can just slide my license and one credit card in the compartment. But that's it! you can not fit anything like currency in there. I attempted to use this all weekend long and it served its purpose. I actually felt liberated I didn't have to carry the heavy wallets around. I received another case from caseguru and the issues I had with that one seemed to have been resolved on this version. The headphone jack is easy to access and the raised rubber buttons are easy to use. Lightening plugs in fine with no interference. The toggle switch is a little difficult to get to for silent mode but not a big deal. Overall it;s a nice case, the color is nice and I think it will hold up for a while. The case is made from a combination of plastic and rubber. The plastic feels cheep with the right hit it will break but you can say that about anything. I am pretty gentle with my devices so I believe this will last a while for me.

PROS:
1. Easy to apply
2. great for days out where you don't want to take much
3. Astatically pleasing (it looks good)

CONS:
1.  Toggle switch for silent is difficult to switch.

Time will tell on the durability of this product, if this product fails or if there are any issues during my use I will update the review in a follow up and adjust my rating accordingly.

SHOULD YOU BUY IT?  Yes

FOLLOWUP: N/A
summary: Quick and Easy for those days you want to travel light.

reviewText: VERY GOOD STUFF

It never really occurred to me that I might be able to power a regular 110  120 volt AC power outlet from my car. So when I saw this power inverter all kinds of possibilities ran through my head and I jumped at the chance to try it.

It arrived in a small box with just the device and a single letter sized sheet pamphlet of instructions. The instructions are brief with about 75% of them being safety warnings and precautions.

Before using it, I quickly inspected the power inverter. It is designed to conveniently fit in a cupholder and is pretty much the shape of the bottom half of a curved taper tall coffee mug with a 2.5 x 2 inch elliptical vent on each side. It has a fairly sturdy in construction with a fairly hefty 15  20amp cable to 12vDV cigarette lighter plug.

Since this is conveniently designed to sit in a cup holder, all the functions are on the top surface which includes a piggyback 12v lighter/accessory socket, a single standard three-prong grounded AC outlet and dual USB 5v charging ports.

In Use

One of the reasons I liked the idea of one of these is that we only have a single vehicle and live in a flood risk area. So I thought this might be a useful tool in an emergency. So I plan on mostly keeping it in the car because it could come in quite handy one day by providing us with much-needed power. I also got it for convenience when camping, charging notebooks on the move or powering an LED work-light or charging RC car batteries with an AC battery charger and powering a fairly loud solid state electric guitar amp.

Using it is pretty straightforward. I was a little concerned because my only car is a Mazda MX-5 which, by todays standards, has a small standard battery.

Despite my initial hesitation, when I plugged the accessory/cigarette lighter plug into the cars 12v power socket I was very pleased with how solid the connection was. The springs on the side are very strong and made a very good snug connection. In my car there is no power supplied till you insert the key and at least turn it to the first accessory stage. When the inverter receives power, a row of LEDs light up to indicate the level of your cars battery. The first one is red indicating low battery. The other three are green.

I really wanted to test the guitar idea because it is something fun Id like to take camping. I have a 10w sound output pam that draws 40w of electrical power. Initially plugging this in on accessory produced 1 red and 2 green power indicator lights. If I turned on the engine then I got all three green lights. The amplifier powers up just fine and worked a treat. I can turn the volume up more than loud enough.  When I turned the engine back off to accessory, the power indicator light still shows all three green LEDs. Work light, dremel tool and powering the notebook all work fine too.

I didn't want to push it with anything like power tools with a large current draw. My car lighter socket has a 15amp fuse.

I found that the power inverter has a fuse inside the plug. You access the fuse by unscrewing the knurled fastner just above the sprung tip. The fuse is rated at 20 amps and 32 volts. So in some cars like mine there is the potential to blow the cigarette lighter fuse before the Sungoldpower inverter fuse blows. 20 amps is quite a lot. It might be worth checking your vehicle and getting a lower spec fuse if you're thinking of using devices that use a heavy load.

The AC outlet socket has a very snug connection so it required quite a bit of strength to pull the three prong AC plug out again. This isn't a bad thing at all.

Conclusion

This is a very handy device that will provide a decent AC power source similar to your wall outlets at home. I played my guitar for a good half hour no problem after using it. I haven't used it for much else but am very happy. If you're going to power something for a long period you will probably want the engine running so the car battery keeps charging. I have a really small car that doesnt have any convenient cup holders since there are only two inside the center console and you cant change gear with the manual stick-shift when they are being used. But my car is the exception. Most American cars have an abundance of cup-holders..

Even so, Im giving this a 5 stars. I really like it, it does a good job, seems well made, is dependable and offers a lot of possibilities, especially if you like road trips and camping or travel a lot because of work.

Disclaimer: I received this inverter in exchange for an honest and fair review.  The opinions expressed are my own.

reviewText:
Just to be clear, I love the feel and the look of this phone. This has the potential of competing with Samsung, Nexus and dare I say it, Apple. The display is great, the metal back feels smooth, and the front facing speakers (make that speaker) looks cool.
The problems I have are the following:
Battery life: You'll get a full days worth IF you keep it in standby, forget about using it to watch videos or surf FB all day, you'll only get 4-6 hours b4 recharging.
Bootloader Unlock/Rooting: ZTE does not allow to unlock the bootloader and there's no way to root it either. BIG NEGATIVE for me.
Speakers: There are two front-facing speaker grills but only one works for playing music or handsfree talking. WTH?
Smooth Design but; Also very slippery with dry hands, and since I don't use lotion this is a problem.
Weight: The phone is too heavy, especially since the battery life sucks.

So if you can live with the above issues, by all means, go ahead and get it, the price is cheap.
summary: Possible Flagship Phone, drops the ball.

reviewText:
My previous phone was HTC One M8 and I switched to Blu Life One a week ago. I am very impressed with the performance of this smartphone. It IS equipped with high-end components such as Snapdragon 410 processor, 1GB RAM, 13 mega pixel Sony IMX135 camera sensor, but the price is only about one third of HTC One M8.

Blu Life One accepts dual SIM cards. When I am travelling overseas, I can put T-Mobile USA SIM card on one and the other is reserved for the foreign SIM card.

The display resolution, HD 720 x 1280, accompanied with Corning Gorilla Glass is awesome. If you are into selfie, you'll be amazed with the wide angle 5 mega pixel resolution of the front camera.

However, one disappointment I find on this camera is the screen glare in bright sunlight. Other than that, this is a perfect phone if you think performance and price.
summary: Perfect combination of PERFORMANCE and PRICE

reviewText:
I bought the first couple of iPhones when they first came out and use my wife's every now and then and I've also owned 4 or 5 different android devices and the note series is by far my favorite. I purchased a Note 2 when it first came out and loved it so I decided to go with the note 3 and it is an even better version of an already great phone.

I was debating between this, the S5, and the HTC One M8 but I went with the note and took the "hit" in processing power for and extra Gb of ram (which is amazing).

I've already rooted and installed the hyper drive rom but even without the extras of a custom rom this phone has so many features that make it a fantastic productivity tool.

The S Pen alone is something that I use literally every day at work to take meeting notes. I work with meeting software that allows you to share your screen so I can do that while also taking nones on my Note 3 without showing everyone what I'm writing down. Then I sync with evernote and have all of my notes in the cloud, it's perfect.

Fantastic phone with a great price here on amazon, couldn't be happier.
summary: Fantastic phone for those who want to be productive

Sometimes defective products get put in packages, it happens. Such is life. What happens after a customer receives a defective product is what makes the product from good to great.

I sent my girlfriend on a road trip with a brand new package of cables, she had a decaying old one in her car that would barely stay in the phone, and one didn't work at all. The other was loose in the phone after a few minutes.

I was frustrated, but I emailed them, and they're more than willing to help. I was sent a brand new package. I certainly stand behind a company that stands behind their products.
summary: What happens after a customer receives a defective product is what makes the product from good to great

reviewText:
This is a good mount with just a couple issues.  I have the Note 4 with a very slim case on it.  Feels like if I had a more substantial case, this mount would not be able to open wide enough for it to fit. As my phone is now though it does fit just fine. I've had it two weeks now through warm and freezing weather and the mount is still stuck where I put it. It has not fallen  yet. Granted, the Note 4 is big and heavy but the mount shakes quite a bit when I'm driving over rough pavement. It was a little distracting at first but since it has fallen yet I'm not too worried about it. For the price (I paid around $10) this mount cannot be beat.  I recommend it.

Edit a month later - After a few more weeks of use the mount broke when I was trying to put my phone in it.  The body separated from the suction cup rendering this mount useless.  I have therefore changed by rating from four stars to one star and would put zero stars in if I could.  I don't usually have issues with things from Amazon but this is one of thost rare times.  I don't recommend you buy this.
summary: Initially this was good, but after more use it broke

reviewText:
I've been using my headset for four months now and have loved it.  I typically use it for listening to podcasts and audio books while I'm working, and for that purpose, it works wonderfully.  I've heard the sound quality isn't so great for music, but to be honest, my hearing isn't sharp enough to tell where it's lacking.

My only complaints are with actual phone calls.  I've heard from people I've called that it picks up a lot more wind and background noise that my old Voyager 510 did.  There also seems to be a bit of a delay (less than 1/4th of a second) between when I start speaking, and when the mic starts picking me up.  It's fine if I take the time to speak clearly, but tends miss short, one word replies completely.
summary: Great for podcasts and audio books, OK for music and phone calls

Initial impression:  Upon unboxing my very first impression was wow this thing is huge!.  With the belt clip this is quite the beast.  So if you are looking for a svelte, unassuming case read no further, this isn't made for you.  However, if you are looking for a dual layer protective case that has the added benefit of providing an additional 160% battery life then this may suit your needs.

Pros:
-  First and foremost is the additional battery life provided.  The 4600 mAh battery will extend life approximately 160% over stock.  Your mileage may vary, as I tend to use my phone while charging.  You may get more life if you aren't as heavy a user.
- The battery itself is removable and can be changed out rather easily with another.
- Overall the case provides good protection.  The inner hard plastic shell is a cinch to install and remove.  The iPhone 6 slides into the bottom half and mates with the lightning connector, then the front/side portion of the plastic case is snapped into place.  Finally the outer soft shell is slipped over and locks into a ridge running along the entire front of the plastic case.  Removal is just as easy reversing the previous process.
- As noted earlier the battery is removable, it sits in a compartment built into the back of the plastic hard case.  Its held in place by the soft shell.
- The face of the phone is left open, a screen protector is provided with the case.  I prefer this to the ones with a plastic covering over the screen and the home button.  Theres no interference with touch ID and the screen sensitivity is not affected.
- The forward facing speaker holes do a good job in redirecting the audio towards you when watching the screen.
- The volume and power button covers are well done and very responsive.
- The charging and earphone ports are well covered and sits in place nicely
- The charging button is located on the front and is easily accessible, as is the battery charge indicator.
- The belt clip is well made with multiple adjustments to carry the phone vertical, horizontal and numerous angles in between.  The case has depressions built into the sides which the clip locks into.  It should hold well under normal conditions.

Issues:  There were a couple of items that detracted from the overall functionality of the case.
-  The cover for the mute switch was loose and did not close well.  Theres a small tab that locks into a small hole in the side of the plastic case.  Unfortunately with the size of the cover the tab doesnt do a very good job of holding it in place.  The cover usually popped open with minimal disturbance, allowing dust/dirt to enter.
- My biggest pet peeve was the earphone adapter.  If used with the original iPhone buds everything worked well.  The connector of the Apple buds fit perfectly into the earphone adapter and was easily plugged into the phone.  The problem comes in with 3rd party earphones/buds, depending on how the connector is styled you may or may not be able to use the earphone adapter (more than likely not).  If not youll have to use the supplied metallic earphone jack.  Heres where the problem lies, the supplied jack doesnt fit into the earphone adapter at all. This means you have the adapter laying around outside of the case and not attached in anyway, making it easy to lose/misplace.  And if you lose the plastic earphone adapter the front facing speaker holes don't work very well as the majority of the sound escapes out of the unblocked earphone jack port.  My felling is that the supplied metallic jack should at least fit with the supplied plastic earphone adapter.  If you rarely or never use earphones/earbuds this probably won't bother you at all.

Final thoughts:  I feel this case fills a niche market nicely.  If you require a good protective case with dual layer shock protection and you're away from charging facilities for more than a day or two at a time this case will fill your needs very well.  The earphone jack issue is a big problem if you use 3rd party earbuds/earphones and are one to insert/remove them numerous times throughout the day.  With the metallic adapter theres just too much opportunity to lose/misplace the plastic earphone adapter.
The additional battery capacity is really nice.  I was able to go 2 days without connecting my phone to a charger.
I rate this case a 3.5 - 4 out of 5 stars.  If the earphone adapter issue could be corrected such that the supplied metallic earphone jack fits into the adapter this phone, I would give it a solid 4 star rating.

Disclaimer - I was provided this case without charge as a sample to review. My review is based solely on my personal use of the item. Other than the case, there was no additional compensation by ZeroLemon for my review or my opinion.
summary: Solid contendor for a dual layer battery case

I was lucky enough to be able to buy the Samsung Gear VR Innovator Edition directly from Samsung. It was one of the reasons I bought a Note 4 when they came out. I am not a VR fan boy, and have never used an Oculus VR system of any type. After installing a phone update from Verizon, and an application from Oculus (there are easy to follow directions with the system), I was ready to go. The phone slides in pretty easy but the downside is that I have to remove my S-Flip cover and use the original back. The phone won't fit properly with the flip cover installed. My initial impression was non-dramatic as you are presented with a few screens of safety information to agree to. I then got busy installing some experiences and games from the Oculus Store (done from the phone either within the Gear VR or using the phone normally). I was then absolutely blown away by my experiences, and while I won't go through all the games and experiences available as of this review (not too many yet but more released every week), I do want to cover some of the best that I would highly suggest you check it out right away. 1. Cirque de Soleil's Zarkana - this experience was my first and although it is not the best or the longest, it immediately shows you what a 360 degree world looks like. You can not only experience the show from the stage, but you can turn around and see other stage actors and the large theater that was empty at the time it was recorded. 2. Strangers with Patrick Watson - I had never heard of Patrick Watson before, so if you like his music then you will really loved this one. It puts you into his studio apartment (I assume) while he practices a bit on the piano and sings a little. The audio really does sound like you are right there with him in his home. Be sure and look to his left to see his dog - a nice touch I thought. 3. Anshar Wars - this was the 2nd game I tried out, and the best so far in my opinion. You are flying a spaceship and fighting an alien enemy. I played for about an hour the first time and the whole VR experience never bothered me, but I would suggest people who get easily car sick to take it really easy. It works without a controller, but I would suggest getting a controller anyway because it improves the experience and some games require it. 4. Ocean Rift - take a dive and experience some ocean creatures up close and personal. I found this pretty cool although not something I would view often. 5. Titans of Space - This is not a game so much as a tour of the Solar System. It does a really good job of giving you an idea of size of the planets and moons in our solar system. The graphics are not totally awesome, but the experience is neat. 6. Oculus 360 Videos - this application has quite a few videos that are really cool to watch. One of my favorite is called 360 Iceland and is a tour of Iceland. If you get motion sickness, you might want to make sure you are sitting down the first time and be ready to take off the Gear VR if it bothers you. Samsung 360 tours takes you to New York City for another tour - also very enjoyable. 7. Oculus 360 Photos - the sd card comes preloaded with a lot of 360 degree photos. It includes dozens of places and has something for everyone from nature to world renowned landmarks to abandoned places like Chernobyl. Lots to choose from here. 8. Oculus Cinema - I think this will be the most used application on the Gear VR. It comes preloaded with some movie trailers both 3d and 2d, and you have a choice of 4 cinemas to watch movies in - a home theater, a standard movie theater, a theater on the surface of the moon - and a blank theater where all you see is the screen. You have the option of copying your own movies -both 3d and 2d to the SD card of your phone to use with Oculus Cinema. You might want to check out the Oculus Gear VR forum for help in that area. As of the time of this review, there really isn't a "store" yet to buy content such as games and movies, but I am sure that will be available soon and will make the Oculus Cinema a true entertainment system that lets you go to the movies anytime you want and get a true cinema experience. Suggested Accessories: 1. Controller - I use the PlayPad Pro for Amazon Fire TV with my Gear VR and it works fine so far. I'm not sure about advanced games since there aren't any available right now, but for $20 I think you can't go wrong. 2. Ear Buds - you will want to wear ear buds to truly appreciate the Gear VR experience. Overall, I was completely thrilled with the Gear VR, and the $200 cost if you already have a Note 4 is a no brainer. If you don't have a Note 4 and don't want one, I am not sure it is worth the cost of both, but if you can justify a Note 4 for everyday cell phone use and can afford the $200 for the Gear VR, I would highly recommend it.
summary: Thrilled With My Samsung Gear VR - Some Things You Need To Know

You might think that cases are only for the anal retentive that care about keeping their phone pristine, but there's more to it than that. Things you want to think about include:

Drop Protection: Look, no matter how careful you are, gravity is just stronger than you. You'll probably drop your phone at least once or twice in the years that you own it. How much protection you need, though, depends on your phone: lots of Android phones are built a bit tougher, and are more likely to survive the occasional drop (I'm speaking from lots of experience here). The iPhone 4 or 4S, on the other hand, while blessed with gorgeous looks, are a lot more likely to break when you drop them, so the argument for using a case becomes much stronger.

It's also worth mentioning that even cheap cases can give you drop protection by preventing you from dropping the phone in the first place. A lot of phones have particularly slippery backs, and a good case can add a bit of grip to keep it from sliding out of your hand and onto the concrete. It still isn't as good as getting a quality case, but it's better than going naked.

Protection for More Than Just Cosmetics: Even if you don't care about the occasional scratch or even shattered back, there's more to your phone than that. Some phones (like the iPhone) have a camera lens flush with the back, meaning its much more prone to scratches and other damagewhich can make your photos look pretty awful. You could also damage one of the buttons on your phone, which would make it much more of a hassle to use than just a few scratches.

Resale Value: That said, even if you aren't obsessive about the little scratches on your phone, many people areand while dropping your phone without a case may not break it, it will create little nicks and scratches on your phone that will lower the resale value. Putting a case on your phone is one of the best ways to upgrade to your next phone for freeso if you sell your phones instead of keeping them around, a case can be a great idea.

Stand Out in a Crowd: While there's always an argument to make for "individuality", a case can also make you stand out in a practical way. Next time you're at a social gathering, count the number of people with the same phone as you in the room. Now imagine none of those people had cases on their phones, and left them on the table or counter (as so many people do). Have fun finding your phone in a sea of identical iPhones.
summary: such a nice sleek phone case
